Quite much pitch black colour with beigeish brown head. Aroma is roasted malts, some tar as well as mild smoked wet wood and some slight ashes as well. Flavour is very much tar, smoked wet wood, slight roasted malts as well as old coffee. Rather mouthfilling feeling while having this.

Bottle shared at JoeMcPhees during the 2010 Winter Olympics Gold Medal hockey game: Pours a very deep murky brown with a khaki film of head. Great rich aroma- smoky, chocolaty, anise, very rich and chewy. Creamy silky body with a richly malty flavor. Dark chocolate, earthy smoke, peat, salty licorice, clean roast, and lots of peppery hops to dry it out. The finish is long, rounding, salty and bitter. Awesome!
Short and sweet: If you like a "smoke porter", this is for you. Enjoy.

Sweet smoky aroma. Smoke instantly noticeable. Completely opaque body with a tan head. Not much lace. Sweet, smoky flavor that clearly has strength but not overly so. One of the better rauchbiers Ive had.

Left Hand Brewing Company-Smoke Jumper Smoked Imperial Porter--Big Mo Series--2008-9 Release--22 oz. Bottle--9.20% ABV--67 IBUs.  (4.5 / 5.0)  Porter--Smoked--Thick pour.  Headless lace hint.  Clear dark red brown color.  Rich smoky floral chocolate hop front.  Mild creamy sweet rich smooth doughy chocolate malt integrated balanced smoke body.  Loose BC sediment adds more creamy notes.  Cloying malt hop spice EtOH end.  Sampled 1/24/2009.  $5.49 Each.

Bottle, shared with the in-laws while playing cards. Pours a near-black with a rocky, lively brown head that takes ages to settle. Big meaty smoky aroma with underlying roast and sweet nuances. Big meaty smokiness on the palate, but married perfectly to generous roast and chocolate malts. Mouthfeel is on the heavier side. As the palate re-calibrates in the face of a smoky explosion, the sweeter dak malts play forward, giving more depth to this beautifully crafted beer. Finish is modestly bitter and a little salty. Wow I loved this one!
user_location: the land of bitumen, beef & beer, Alberta, CANADA

text: Draft at redlight redlight.  pours a dark brown.  amazing aroma.  more of a sugar-cured ham than bacon, peat, or campfire.  hints of dark malt come through as well.  Surprisingly subtle flavor.  The smokiness makes way for a slightly sweet taste.  Extremely smooth and easy to drink for a beer with such a strong nose.  This one takes the cake.

08 bottle from Kahns, shared with Brother Eric. Pours very dark with barely noticeable ruby transparency and nice caking beige head. Nose is brilliant campfire smoke, burnt wood, burnt chocolate, burnt molasses. Flavor is soft, smooth and semi-creamy, dark bitter smoked-ash-meat, and a touch of molasses and chocolate as well. Finish leaves more of the meat flavor and ash.  Smoke character is truly excellent.  9.8 has melded perfectly...dangerously. I am ready to pitch a tent and build a fire...this beer is motivating.

22oz bomber, 2008 vintage, from greens in columbia. pours a deep, dark brown that is damn near black as smoke, with a full, creamy, khaki head and thick lacing. aroma is outstanding with huge notes of smoke and ashy wood, dark chocolate, dark fruits, and bitter coffee with unique notes of salt-cured bacon, smoked salmon, and a hint of mesquite. flavor is excellent as well and everything i expected from the aroma with big, smoked meats, roasted malts, burnt coffee, and charred wood up front with sweet undertones of chocolate, caramel, and vinous fruits leaving a bitter, ashy finish. palate is medium bodied and quite smooth with solid carbonation. overall, and great smoked porter.

08 Bomber just enjoyed an hour ago. Pours a nice deep brown nearly black with a thick billowing tan head. Aroma is very smoky with a very nice roasted chocolate malt character, some dark fruits. Really nice balance of sweet cocoa, smoky earthy character and dark fruits. Flavor is delicious, starting smoky and sweet, super rich chocolate, cocoa powder, hints of sweet licorice and a very warming roastiness. The flavor gets woody in the middle and the smoke really kicks in along with a sharp bitter chocolate note that remains prevalent through the finish, which holds just enough sweetness to keep it balanced. Medium to full silky smooth creamy body and a strong carbonation that was a bit much as first faded nicely over time. What a well balanced warming beer, didnt pick up any booziness. All around great stuff.
Pors deep brown with a cascading head.  Notes of smoke and coffee on the nose.  deep smoke notes with a burnt malt and espresso flavor drive into a nice full cocoa driven finish.

(Bottle, 0.65 l) Poured black with small and tan coloured head. Aroma contained roastedness, sweetness and tar. Palate was close to full bodied and bit dry with quite high carbonation. Flavours were strongly tar, smoke, burntness, roastedness, bitterness, cough mixture and bitterness. Aftertaste was burnt, smoky and bitter.

Bottle. Deep rich brown with slight ruby highlights, thick foamy tan head mostly sustains, wet lacing on the glass. Nose is beechwood-like smoke, roast, and chocolate. Flavor is that of a light-moderate rauchbier with smoke malts and meats dominant throughout, sweet roastiness, tinges of dark chocolate underneath the smoke, finishes on the sweet side. Full body, thick creamy texture, moderate carbonation. A modest smokey porter that is not as jarring as the traditional German variants, the sweet highlights help provide depth.

Sampled 12/18/2009. 2008 bottle. This smoked beer pours a eclipse brown color from a 22oz bottle. Medium sized tan foamy head. The aroma is chocolate, coffee. Smoke and wood. A medium to full bodied smoked porter. The malts are chocolate, coffee, smoke and wood. The hops are earthy and floral. Nice carbonation. A nice blend of smoke, chocolate, coffee and malts, all the flavor mix and match together nicely there is no one aspect trying to overwhelm. Very smooth tasting. Mouthfeel is full and round. Finish is clean and smooth. Aftertaste is slightly bitter.
Just like drinking liquid bacon from a campfire.  Take this one with you on you adventure in the woods.

22 oz bottle. Pours black with a thick foamy tan head. Aroma is chocolate, caramel, smoke and roasted malt. The flavor is smokey, roasted malt that along with some hops give this a strong bitterness, the big sweet malt base helps to balance out the beer though, alcohol is well hidden. Full body with soft carbonation and a thick smooth mouth feel. This is a very nice Imp Porter with a great smoke flavor that adds up to an outstanding beer.

black pour, huge creamy tan head.
aroma is smoked meat, campfire, some good roasted malt chocolate tones. 
Flavour is chocolatey and  pretty smokey. a trace of dark fruit and some dry bitterness in the finish.

the smell activates my appetite for food... bbq smoked salmon, jerky...
it almost comes across savory, which ive never gotten from a brew before.
overall criticism, its a bit thin and watery in the middle and lacks complexity.
But a solid drinkable smoke with nice hops on the finish.

Bottle 2008. Pours very dark brown color with khaki head.  Mmmmmmm.....smoked meat aroma. Burnt malt flavor wiith a good amount of smokiness. Medium to full body with soft carbonation. A very nice beer.

Serving date: 2009-03-15. Best before: December 2010. Served in snifter.

Very dark brown, almost black. Considering the style and high ABV the the pale brown, thick and creamy head is rather big and leaves plenty of lacings.

The smell is mostly of smoked meat (ham), some sweet chocolate notes, roasted malts. Beneath the massive smoke aromas, light hops are also present.

The taste has some big and powerful, but not overpowering, smoke flavors: smoked meat (ham, bacon), burnt wood/forest fire, charcoal, peat. Some general roastiness. Plenty of sweet flavors as well: chocolate, soft chocolate nougat, light caramel, coffee, some malts. Some saltiness (might be the smoked bacon). Again, faint hops are present. Seems like there is a very good porter base in this brew. The finish is considerably bitter and contains some caramelized sugar, burnt wood and spicy alcohol (however, the alcohol hides rather well). The taste of smoked sausage lingers on for quite a while in the mouth.

Full body, light carbonation. Feels very smooth and calm. It gets a bit sticky after a while.

A very good smoked beer. Complex smoke aromas coupled with an equally complex porter profile makes for a pleasant drinking experience. It gets a little to much after a while though and the palate takes quite a beating. A bomber is just slightly to much, but great for sharing.

Serving type: bottle

(Copy of old Beer Advocate review)

bomber - 2008 vintage; thick, dark brown and cola clear along the edges; thin, soapy off white head; smoked malt, roasted grains; aromas are quite rich with a dry smoke and meaty quality to it; lots of roast too and super dry in the finish; more of a smoked than a porter and generally I like the opposite; some chocolate and malty sweetness, but this had a little much on the smoke for my liking

22oz Bottle, purchased somewhere in the Philadelphia area. Dense, creamy deep woods smoke, with plenty of freshly smoked whitefish and lake trout. Rich, woodsy and mystical. Absolutely enticing. Falls in a thick murky dark brown, with plenty of jiggling, creamy sand-colored head. Flavor, again, reminds me immediately the luscious maple-smoked fat on the belly of a piece of lake whitefish, taking me home to Michigans Upper Peninsula. A wash of porter chocolate, ale alcohol, and bright well-complimenting water minerals follow, adding balance and depth. The smoke starts to fade here, giving way to the darker malt characters, some yeast esters, and satisfying alcohol and sugar. The smoke quality is incredible, but its a bit too light for me. Id like to see it sustain through to the finish better and not lay down to the porter malts so much. Nonetheless, certainly an enjoyable beer.
Bottle. Pours near black with a thin head. The aroma is roasty and smoky with a light sweetness. The flavor has really nice smoky notes with a roasty finish and a light sweetness. Very good.

UPDATED: DEC 10, 2009 This beer smells insanely delicious, smoky bacon is a favorite even though I dont eat pork anymore.  Appearance is a hard to see through dark black but the head was smaller than I expected.  The taste contains a lot of the great flavors from the nose but was a bit bitter.  Overall, the beer was very interesting but Im not crazy about the style other than the nose.

2008 BOTTLE CONDITIONED (Says on the label)

Nice dark black liquid. Three finger head of light brown foam. Great retention and fairly good lacing.

No denying that this one is smoked. Smoke is the first thing you smell, and its quite prominent. Also, some leather. Smells of top quality smoked bacon, actually. Some roasted malt presence. Slight caramel notes.

Its like liquid smoke. Wow.
Nice herbal hops bite. Roasted grains. Some dark chocolate notes. Nice undercurrent of coffee. Hints of smoked pork. Trace notes of vanilla and caramel. Good molasses presence.

Good full-bodied porter. Slight oily-ness is sneaking in. Nice level of creaminess. Fairly impressive, actually.

A smooth easy drinker, as far as the body goes. The dominant smokiness would probably keep me from drinking more than a couple in one sitting, though.

From the Bottle at TAG Restaurant, Denver 22/09/2009
Smoky roast aroma. Dark red coloured and strong in alcohol with a little dryness in a hoppy and bitter smoked roast malt finish.

An almost opaque molasses pour, with a nice, thick brown head that reduces to a thin cap, leaving sparse lace.  Some tobacco, smoked peat, bacon, jerk spices, and rich malts to the nose.  The flavors center in on smoked meats (bratwurst), peat, dark malts, bitter chocolate, and dark fruit esters. Smoky bitters and jerk spices close the finish, lingering nicely.  A tad of alcohol is noted, but superbly integrated.  A smooth, yet rich mouthfeel with a full body and light carbonation levels, this is an excellent impy smoked porter!  Perfect for the colder months.

Pours black with a thick light brown head. Aroma is bacon, chocolate, vanilla and some soy. Taste is much the same with rich bacony chocolate. Thick creamy texture and a nice roasty finish. Very tasty.

Pours an impenetrable black with a decent one finger caramel head. Head hangs around for the duration leaving thin consistent lacing on the side of the glass goblet.

Aroma is very enticing. Smokey, yet sweet. Raisins and dates come threw the campy smoke. Overly roasted malts. Also had a dryness to it.

Taste is great! The over roasted malts shine threw, giving it a smokey and not burnt flavor. Raisin and dates again, coffee and chocolate. There is a slight bitter pine in the finish along with a warming sensation from the ABV. Alcohol doesnt really come into play with the taste, but you can feel it in the finish.

Mouthfeel is good for a beer of this depth. Carbonation is complimenting. Only slightly oily from the malts.

Drinkability is also good for this style. This bomber will not have any problems being consumed in this sitting. A great smoked porter from a brewery I have never heard of before. Will be trying to find some more stuff from these guys!

Bottle Pours out a smokey brown topped with a smokey cream head. Aroma of smoke, sweet malts, and smoked pork. Ahhh smoked pork. Sorry I am back now. Taste was not of smoked pork but of smoke, sweetness, molasses and rich malts.

2008.  Pours a dark, dark brown with a beautiful coffee and cream head.  The nose is slightly sweet with a generous amount of smokehouse and bacon.  Beer has a nice big mouthfeel with an earthy, salty, meaty mid palate. Finish has a good bitterness and mild sweetness that really works.  Great beer for a cold winter day.

750mL bottle, vintage 2006.  Poured deeper brown with a thick, creamy, well-set cap of tan head.  The aroma picked up sweet, soft, and salty bacon notes upfront with darker chocolates, molasses, and a little tar behind.. fresh oak and vanilla waft through.. tangy, woody character left the final impression.  The flavor opened with sharp-ish smoke and oaky notes, backed quickly by burnt coffee, molasses, and a touch of tobacco.. salty smoke was laced throughout and amplified by alcohol warmth.. more of the deeply-roasted dark malts and smoke on the long finish with a grainy, earthy and woody bitterness.  Heavier-bodied and quite well carbonated on the palate.. dry and grainy.. just a little sharp at times, otherwise it felt good.  Excellent brew, and I dont think the age hurt it a bit.

Sample f/22oz Bomber-Black pour w/a slight tan head. Aroma of smoked wood. Classic Smoked, flavors of smoked wood, peat, molasses, some dark chocolate & coffee. This is one of those big brews which would be perfect sitting around the fire on a cold winter night. Great after dinner sipper. Long earthy finish, very enjoyable.

08 bottle. Pours black with a nice creamy, lasting brown head. Intoxicating aroma of chocolate, smoke, molasses, alcohol, and heavy cream. Very potent. Creamy mouthfeel with subtle flavors of smoke and charcoal. Hints of licorice, chocolate and smoked malts. Just a touch of sweetness, with a very bitter, campfire finish. Overall, my favorite smoked beer. Very interesting and satisfying.
shared a bomber pours a dark black with a stong smokey smell thin head. hints of smoked meat chocolate and so much going on but very yummy

9/28/09 notes:  poured at GABF.  Nose is smoky, roasted malt, with dry chocolate.  Flavor is smoked wood, dried meats, and dark chocolate.  Actually fairly successful in pulling off this style.  Body is medium, which in this case is ideal, since a full body with these flavors would make the whole thing too weighty.

After finding out that this beer won a gold medal at this years (09) GABF, I just had to try it. And it is worthy, IMO. SmokeJumper pours dark, with a lofty, light tan head. The beer has a bold smokiness, but its not overpowering. Malts oozed with dark chocolate, peat, treacle and bread crust. Roasty-toasty aromas, along with an element of campfire, followed.

Flaske: Sort let gennemsigtig øl med et fint brunt skum. Diskret duft af røg og sød malt. Smagen er igen diskret røg med en god gang portersødhed i sig. Virkelig en delikat balance. Røgen spiller rigtig godt med sødmen og ingen af delene bliver for meget. Alkoholen er helt skjult. Fantastisk øl.

Deep black pour with a thick, sticky dark brown head.  The nose is lovely.  Rich, sweet dark malts.  Deep cocoa, coffee, and toffee along with a nice bitter chocolate character late.  Also has a lovely soft smokiness over this dark maltiness.  The palate is rich and silky but with a bit of ashiness that dries it out a bit on the back.  Its sweet but there is a dried leathery character that gives it a nice complexity.  Count me a fan of this.

Bottle. Moderate malt aromas of dark bread and toasted, light resin and leather for the hops and yeast, with background notes of smoke, charcoal and cola. Head is small, frothy, light brown, with no lacing and is almost fully diminishing. Color is black. Flavor starts moderately sweet and lightly acidic, then finishes lightly sweet and acidic and moderately bitter. Palate is medium to full, watery with a lively carbonation. This is definitely the boldest and yet most easy drinking Smoked Ive had.
This is like Bacon in a glass! The smokey flavor overpowers everything else but its a beer like nothing youve had before! You really need to try it, but I"m sure most people wouldnt like it.
Aroma of toffe, coffe and smoke. Appearance is dark as the night with a big nice head. The flavor is bitter and smokey with hints of coffe and vanilla. A very nice beer with a sudle smokey taste.

A nose of vanilla, coffee and smoke. Taste is of vanilla, smoke, coffee and oak. Its massive and pretty bitter, but the smokey character has mellowed a bit - to reveal a solid imperial porter! Im usually not very fond of smoked brews, and Ive only been disappointed by products from Left Hand, but this is something else entirely. I regret that I didnt buy another bottle when I had the chance.

Shared a 750 with Dr Jay, pour is dark with a rich brown head and good lacing. Smells of tar, and tobacco, pine, chocolate and soy sauce. A rich nose for a rich beer. The taste is slightly sweet with a liquid smoe quality. Some prune,coffee and molasses. Feel is light but not watery.

750 ml. bottle. Vintage 2006. Bottle conditioned. 10.5 % ABV on label actually 9.8. Shared with Gabe. Pours a thick mocha head of long duration with some lacing, over a clear, very dark, (SRM 36) with red tones body....nose of smoke, bit of bacon, soy, molasses, coffee, chocolate....taste initially quite sweet, then smoke , molasses, dried fruit, finishing with woody astringancy....mouth feel surprisingly light, carbonation low. A very interesting, remarkably complex and subtle brew.

Bottle shared with the guys at the Inglorious Emergency Tasting. August 31st with Butters. Ill start by saying that this is easily the best Left Hand beer Ive ever had. Its also the best Porter Ive ever had. Nothing comes close. Dark brown in color with a nice silky tan head. Notes of smoke, pork fat, bacon, and beef jerky.  Supple beer. Wonderful mouth feel. Creamy as hell and fat as shit. But it has just enough acid like substance to cut through the fat. Butters is in love. Maybe the best beer Ive ever had..... Part 2 - Okay decided to revisit this beer after we all went crazy over it at our tasting. Im lowering my score .2. The smoke qualities can be overwhelming especially when you first open the bottle. However, the Smokejumper opens up quite nicely given some swirls and a few minutes. If you dont like smoke, this beer isnt for you. However, if you like cigars and beer together, Smokejumper is your new best friend. 

Overall: This is an excellent beer that description cannot do justice. While not my favorite beer of all time, it is exactly what I want for this particular style of beer. Holy Sh!t!!! This is Fing good

Opened after seeing Butters praise.  Dark dark brown, light red hints.  Big loose but puffy dark tan head.  Aroma is smoke, a bit of tingling spiciness from the smoke, campfire ash, chocolate, dry.  The taste is silky smooth smoke.  Not biting at all but lots of smoke in the form of real smoke cured bacon, campfire, smooth chocolate body.  Nice stuff.  Goes down velvety smooth.

Bottle shared with the guys at the Inglorious Emergency Tasting.  Pours a black with good tan head.  Nose of amazing bacony smoke, with a spectacular roasty malt undertones.  Flavor is just as amazing, dark malts, plums, roast, toffee, smoke, ham, bacon.  This is the perfect blend of a perfect porter with the perfect balance of smoke. Truly amazing brew.

200th rating, and what a pick! Pours a dark brown with a thick tan head, and the lacing! Aroma of choice beef jerky, smoke, roasted malts. Fantastic balance of everything a enjoy in a good beer. Excellent!
Pours a slightly lacing tan head and a dark brown body.  Smells like a bacon on dark bread sandwich.  Flavor is a toasted, bacon and dark bread sandwich.  Smoky finish.
pours dark with small brown collar of foam. the intensely smokey smell and taste hide the alcohol almost comletely. goes down smooth.

UPDATED: OCT 14, 2009 Bottle shared at a BA tasting.  This didnt go over well with the group, but I enjoyed it.  Darkest brown in color with a tan head that lasts.  Aroma of smoke, coffee, meat, earth, and a little band-aid.  Flavor smoky and roasty with meaty/bacony notes, coffee, anise, and unfortunately a little band-aid too - which a bunch of people disliked, but I thought was not too much of a detriment.  Mmmmm, band-aids!  ABV well-hidden.  Palate fairly full with a long smoky aftertaste.  Its no Alaskan Smoked Porter, but its pretty good stuff.

Re-rate: tried this again at GABF 2009.  Its good!  Band-aid note is still sort of there, but its really not too big of a deal.  Great smoked meat flavors make up for that and more.

Bottle. Very dark brown with a lasting small brown head. Aroma: smoke, smoked meat, sweet malt, lapsang tea, licorice, light horse/cow manure, a bit of hops. Flavor: smoked, malty, a bit sweet, licorice, coffee, light saltiness, menthol notes (from the hops). Not much trace of the alcohol. Actually rather easy-drinking. Nice!

[Tap] Pours a very dark brown color with a very small tan head. Aroma of smoked malt and wood. The taste is quite smoky, with coffee and light burnt meats. The beer has a syrupy texture, but the alcohol is still noticeable. Strong flavor and full bodied. Quite enjoyable!
This is a hazy dark brown pour with a tan head. The aroma of smoked meats hits you as it does in the flavor. Not as smokey as say the Schlerenka (sp?) but really nicely done and enjoyable

Found this one to shar ewith Uncle Steve, Our Beer Pimp Brian, the deputy Dawg Celticbrew, and the reincarnated Superman, Drbayern.
Poured BLACK!  The off white head disipates to a lacing on the edge, before disappearing alltogether!  The aroma is that of smoky malt.  The smoke flavor is intense and explodes in your mouth.  Great smoke flavor throughout the glass.  I can drink this smoked beer and not choke!

Black color, with a huge rocky head, brownish. There is an initial aroma of smoke and dark malts, followed by light phenol and liquorice. Good body strength and structure, with an excellent chocolate flavor nicely corrected by a delicate smoke touch; it has a fair sweetness level that balances the dark flavors; in the end there is a hint of roasted malts and liquorice, not intrusive; the bitterness is quite strong, and the alcohol produces a pleasant warmth. Very good beer.

(bomber) Pours a black, muddy color with tiny, black particles.  Light brown, medium head - good lacing.  Smokey, malt aroma with hints of molasses.  Sweet malt flavor with hints of smokiness.  Slick texture, average carbonation, long duration, light, bitter finish.

Compliments of doboy (thanks Ed), shared with the boys in da hood.  Poured from bomber, dark brown, almost black, off brown foamy head.  Aroma pungent with smoke of course, burnt malts espresso.  Flavour much the same, not a fan of smoked stly beers, this one was strong.  Smoked beer lovers would enjoy this one.  Overall decent.
user_location: The Crystal Coast, North Carolina, USA

text: Bottle. Low and quickly disappearing brown creamy head. Black body indeed. Smoke coffee liquorice hops aroma. Creamy smoke coffee liquorice hops flavor with some acidity as well. Low carbonation. Long aftertaste. Alcohol percentage well hidden.

UPDATED: JUL 15, 2009 Hell yeah, this is one hell of a smoked beer.  This is not just a normal "smoked porter".  There is a huge amount of smoked in here.  Aroma and flavor are dominated by smoke and followed by roasted sweet malts. Full body and alcohol is well hidden.  My favorite smoked beer so far.

Freaking delicious. Huge thanks to the good people at Left Hand for bringing this to the Des Moines brew fest, particularly the left hand rep who had everyone push me to the front of the line when the bottle got opened!  Pours a deep brown with a small head. Plenty of smoke and bacon on the aroma. Flavor is awesome very smoky some deep roasty and chocolate notes compliment, but generally its just really smoky and very tasty, the alcohol is particularly well hidden.
At brewfest 09. Lots of ham and bacon. Some caramel in the nose. Very smooth palate. Quite nice.

Dark brown with a thin slowly fading off white head.  Aroma of smoke, caramel, wood and sweet roasted malt.  Taste of caramel, alcohol, sweet and roasted malt and of course plenty of smoked malt.  Some saltiness comes through and the body is semi sticky, but overall a very good example of the style.

Probably one of those beers that speaks to some, but not to others. It speaks to me. It says it is smoky and sweet, bright and sour, bitter and smooth, all in a package that is so natural it is like it grew in a tree. I loved it.

(bottle). Dark brown color with tan particles. Medium tan head. Strong, smokey roasted malt aroma with light hops. Sweet malt flavor with light alcohol. Avg duration. Astringent finish. Slick texture. Moderate carbonation. Good lacing.
Bottle. Pours black with a thin off white head that lingers. A smoky aroma. Flavors of chocolate, hickory, and smoked malts. A good smoked beer overall not too overwhelming and easy to drink.

Pours a rich opaque sable that is just a shade or two from black; head is tan and fairly thick but none too persistent. Strong aroma is smoky and oily with a firm overtone of fine coffee and hints of molasses and caramel. Rich flavor has roast coffee core with touches of molasses, unsweetened chocolate and burnt caramel and just a touch of hops. Texture is smooth and a little syrupy, somewhat tingly, leaving a slightly sweet mocha finish.
Pours black with medium dark tan head.  Aromas of smoked ribs and flavors to match.  Smoke is somewhat overpowering but not too bad.
Black with a huge beige head. Smoked aroma with burned malt, chocolate and chocolate notes. Flavour had tar, burned malt, dark bitter chocolate and loads of smoke. Finished smoked.

a somewhat thin brown pour, thick brown head.
very smokey aroma, with burnt toast, a hint of fish, and some dark chocolate.
flavor is smokey, but not as offensive as anticipated by the aroma. not much else discernable though, some roasted malt and a hint of grass in the finish.
medium body, maybe a bit thin for an imperial porter, and a tad too much carbonation.
Large tan head, dark body.  Smoked barrel aroma, full body with smokey flavor.

Bottle. Aroma of smoked, spicy meats sort of like bratwurst with mustard or something, some smoked cheese notes too, very smokey and very interesting, some sweet roasted malt behind. Flavor really brings out sweet chocolatey malt and adds a distinct bitter component to the smokey, spicy parts. Creamy mouthfeel. Downright luscious.

Poured with LOTS OF HEAD!!!!! (this couldve been lilbeerdoctors ability to pour haha)  Very enjoyable smoked.  Aroma is of smoked meats, though couldnt determine the exact meat I was thinking of.  Mild smokey flavor, definitely enjoyable.

Bottle.  Pours black with a super thick tan head.  Aroma of smoked meats, roasted malt, piney hops.  Flavor of smoked meats (light smoked meats, not as smoky as Id like) and a sweet malt finish.  Palate is not as robust as Id like but this is pretty tasty.  Not my favorite smoked, but up there.
8/4/8/4/14 (3.8/5)
Had at dchmelas.  Very dark and thick body.  VEry smokey, chocolatey and meaty smell.  Taste was over the top smoke and malt.  Awesome.

Bottel 650 ml from systembolget Sweden. Super nice smoke aroma with some liqurich, dark chocolates and caramell tones. Big light brown head over a dark amber brown ale. The head dissapears rather fast to a thin lace. Thick smoke taste with to much smoked burnt malts for a porter, much more like a stoute in its taste.  A very big body but not to much sweetnes. This is a litle to overpowering beer to have a big drinkability. I love to just sit and smell this and have small sips, but a bottle containing 650 ml, more that an english pint gets a little bit to much. I would have liked this beer better in a small 25-33 cl bottle.
22oz Bottle.  Dark brown, big dark tan head.  Strong nose of smoke, jerkey and more smoke.  Big smokey flavor and fairly dry.  Strong and heavy.  Nice.
Draft at Redlight.  Hides the alcohol well.  Smoked ham nose.  Flavors are more malty with a nice smoke presence.  Good smoked beer.

Bomber shared with BConley. Pours thick and black with a thick tan head.Big smoked ham and bitter chocolate aroma, just awesome.Taste is smooth and smoky with some chocolate, really nice and complex. Stunningly good.
Bottle thanks to RCL?  Pours a dark brown with a tan head.  Nose is big with smoked meat!  Wow!  Taste is smoked meat, chocolate and peat malt.  Very tasty!  Medium body with dry finish.
Pours a dark rich almost black color, has a smokey slightly ashy flavor with hints of malt and caramel.

Bomber from Rons.  Pours onyx with 3-finger fluffy brown head...very brown head.  Nose is dark malt, cacao, dark choc, rauchy peaty licorice.  Tastes rich, complex, with heavy dark malt, solid peaty, cacao, and smoked earthy peaty malty notes throughout.  The rauchiness here is subtle, not like Aecht, but more than most.  Another great example of a favorite style of mine, whether you call this a rauch or an impy porter.

Nice bambergy smokeyness with a great load of milk chocolate, dark chocolate, liqourice, truffels and sweet fruity malty goodness underneath. We are talking both in the nose and in the flavour. The body is rather slick, medium to full with low carbonation. The beer finishes with a nice caramell and hop touch alongside lingering smoke. Truly a good beer with a very complete flavour profile.

On tap at Jerrys. Jet black color, foamy latte head. Aroma true to style w/ restrained coffee, bitter chocolate, smoke, chicory, citrus and raisins as it warms up. Flavors of smoke, chicory, bittersweet chocolate and on the downside, strong soapy undertones. Very balanced, starts off sweet and malty and delivers a quick hops bite at the end w/ a smirk. Hides abv well. Medium body, finishing long and dry. Very nice, but for the soap.

22 oz bottle from By the Bottle in Vancouver, WA. Pours out a thick, murky black with a mild tan head. The aroma is pretty much all smoke, a meaty, campfire like smell that both attracts and repulses at the same time. The flavor is an odd mix of bacon, smoked salmon, chocolate and maybe some licorice. Its a little difficult to separate the aroma out from the flavor at times. Finish has a mild hop bite to it. An interesting brew, I feel like Ill need to drink this a couple more times to get a better gauge on it.

The aroma has a gorgeous smoke quality, and underlying this is the roasted malts and sweet fruitiness of a porter.  Also a sort of smoked meat aroma.  Very attractive, very dark brown, almost black, large billowy tan head.  The flavor is like the smoked meat at  campfire, with notes of fruit, chocolate.  Lots of smoke in both aroma and flavor.  Very enjoyable.  The mouthfeel is thick, and creamy, also enjoyable.  The finish is resiny hops, with a tad of the smoke still left, and a slight bit of alcohol, the only place where it is noticeable here (impressive considering the 9.8% ABV).  Excellent beer overall.  Nice representation of this style.

Bottle, thanks to larsniclas for sharing. Black witth a brown head. Leather and smoke aroma, smoked fish, licorice and cocoa notes. Licorice and viol flavor, floral, malty, oily, slaty notes, cocoa and some dark chocolate.

Bottle.  Poured a deep brown/black color with a 3/4 inch, dense beige head that slowly receded to a thick layer.  Aroma of smoke, a sweet meatiness, some roasted malt, light chocolate, and some charred wood.  Moderately sweet, smooth entry with some light chocolate paired with a sweet meatiness that leads into a moderate smokiness with some hints of charred wood paired with a light roastiness that ends with a light vanilla sweetness.    Low to moderate carbonation and smooth on the palate.  Overall, a nice blend of smokiness and porter with the smoke taking the front seat.  Easy to drink and no real sign of the alcohol.  Nice beer from Left Hand.

Pours a dark brownish/black color with a nice tan head. Aromas of smoke,roasted malt, dark fruits and alcohol. Flavors are of smokey malt, and some vanilla. Wonderful smokey aftertaste. This was a wonderful brew!
Bottle shared from Gestapo, thanks- Black pour with good off tan head.  Some sour apple on the nose.  Full mouth feel, smokey but mellow. Head lasts a good long while.  Nice smoker!
0.65l - Ive tried several American takes on the German Rauchbier, and all have failed.  That is until now.  This was like a big smoked pork sandwich in a glass.  Really nice.
What a great smoked porter! Full bodied, brown/black, smoky, roasty, malty. Would love to try this again with some ribs or bbq chicken. As good as it is the price is a little high. Really good!

Bottled:Pours black with a big creamy head. A pillar of foam rose out of the bottle neck. Kippers and smoked ham on the nose. Smooth and well balanced smoked flavour. No alcohol flavour. A pleasure to drink.

It poured nearly black from the big bottle into a snifter type glass, ample chocolate nougat looking head. It smelled lightly of chocolate, more caramel and some booze. I served maybe about at 46 degrees, kind of warm. I sat this for about 2 1/2 months, it must have really mellowed. The bitter smokiness contributes very highly to great bittler chocolate, mellow carbonation, and a little oily. Im not getting any anticipated saltiness, which I had hoped to settle down with a little age. Delicious and potent.
Black pour with a decent beige head. Smokey, roasted malt aroma. Taste is coffee, bacon and chocolate. Not bad, but a bit smokey for my taste. Well made, just not my thing.

Brewed in the USA......... Pours black in color with a medium beige head. Aroma of smoke from a camp fire, bacon and burnt wood. The taste has a smoked meat flavor with some sweet malts and a hint of tobacco. This was a pleasant suprise for me, smooth with a mild bitterness at the finish. I could actually see myself drinking more then one of these. Nice job !!

(Bottle) Pours dark brown, near black with a big and creamy light brown head. Balanced aroma with medium smoked and near medium roasted/burned tones from the malt. Smoked meat, tar, ash, burned wood, liquorice, dark chocolate, nuts and light coffee. The nose is clean with some sharp vodka-like alcohol hints. Light hoppy notes of grass, resin, herbs and apricots. Some dry white pepper, vanilla, cocoa cola and dried figs hints. The flavour holds light to medium sweet caramel and nutty malt tones that blend perfectly with the near medium smoked notes. The alcohol is too present. Nice laidback hop profile of mild resin and grass. The mouthfeel is clean and medium round. Full medium crisp and creamy carbonation. Medium to full bodied. A massive rye bread and smoke ham sensation!

Bottle. Frothy tan head that lasts atop a dark brown body. The aroma is full of smoke with roasted grain and chocolate underneath. Notes of resin and sugar. The flavor is moderately to heavily sweet and moderately bitter. It finishes moderately sweet and moderately bitter. Medium to full body with a vevelty texture. Lively carbonation. Very good despite the smoke being a bit overpowering. Still a nice balance between sweet and bitter.

Bottle (75 cl). Pours a dark liquid with a small dark foam. Smells of smoke, bitter chocolate and ham. The taste has a very strong hint of smoked ham (in Sweden called Lönnberga Skinka). Also some hints of tobacco and dark chocolate.

Bottle, 75cl - Dark brown beer with a large brown head. Aroma is malty sweet with notes of chocolate, smoke and licorice. Flavor is malty sweet with strong roasty notes with hints of smoke, chocolate ad some dry woodiness. A very nice smoke beer!

Pours black with hints of reddish brown near the edges.  Sweet smokey malt aroma, hints of bacon.  As with these usually, the nose transmutes into the flavor, almost directly except for a bite more smoke in the fired burnt department as the beer finishes out on the palate.  Nicely thick, great mouthfeel, good stuff.

Poures brown-black.  Deep khaki head.  Beef jerkey, smoke, bacon, and charcoal bbq aroma.  Bottle had a lot of sediment, flavor was liquid smoke, raisin, and more smokey bitterness.  Very nice balance for smoked beer. excellent.

Bottle.
Pours black with a brown head. 
Sweet smokey aroma.
Rather stoutish but where a stout should become deep and complex the smokey flavour takes over.

Pours dark mahogany out of the bottle and sits almost completely black in the glass with a creamy one-inch head that recedes slowly to a cap.

The aroma is awesome, smells like hickory smoked sausage.  There are some chocolate malts and coffee floating around in the back but the smoked meat aroma dominates.

The taste has a sweet dark malt flavor up front before the smoked meats take over and leave a boozy smoke-filled finish.

The mouthfeel is smooth with lots of smoke and slightly dry in the finish.

This is a great smoked beer, and one that has plenty of smoked character without being overpowering.  Highly recommended.

Bottle. Look: Black. Beige head. Smell: Smoked sausage. Chocolate in the background. Taste: Nice roasted flavors, coffee, dark chocolate etc. For me the smokeiness is disturbing. I think it only makes this brew worse.

Bottled
Black with a large, creamy head.
Leather and stable, burnt and somewhat sourish, licorice and violet, salty and oily (soy-like).

pours hazy brown/black and really too dark to tell otherwise with a purple tinted mocha colored head. random spots of foamy lacing show up on the glass. 

the smoke in the aroma is beautiful... crafted with care as it is sweet, rich and luscious. that smell lays the ground work for prunes, malt, sourness, roquefort/mineral/blood/copper/iron, moss, earthy/woody and slight umami notes to come through. 

the smoke in the flavor is rich (but mild by the standard) yet not so potent that nothing else is tasted... sweet slowly smoked malt, dark raisins,  bitter cocoa, caramel sweetness, lactose and roquefort show up. cheesey roquefort (maybe point reyes... but definitely the roquefortii strain) is odd but is seems to blend wonderfully. mild hoppy bitterness and lingering parching qualities come on during the finish and aftertaste and there are some mineral notes burped up. 

the body is medium and has one of the richest mouth feels... the creamy soft carbonation balances quite well with the sour smoked grain and leaves behind a slight residue on the lips. 8/4/9/5/18/4.4

Botella. Courtesy of Plovmand, thanks a bunch compadre! Pitch black colour with a nice brown head. Smoke and roasted malt in the aroma along with caramel and light bacon. Good mouthfeel. The flavour is very pleasantly smoked with good roasted malt, roasty caramel, some chocolate and a nice bitterness. Smoky roasty long lasting finish. Great smoked.

Bottle. Pitch black body with a dark brown head. Sweet malty aroma with smoke, tobacco and caramel notes. BIt alcoholic as well. The smopke is profound in flavour but I catch notes of caramel, chocolate and tobacco too. Medium bodied.

Bottle from Liquor Max. Pours dark black with a rocky tan head. Aroma is smoke - like a smoked cheese. Full bodied with cramy carbonation. Flavor is smoked malt - heavily smoked. The smoke burns in the mouth. Its not entirely dry. The flavor is smooth dark burnt malt with coffee and chocolate. Finishes magnificently.

Bottle from bhensonb. This dark brown ale poured with a huge fluffy tan head that quickly subsided, and a coffee aroma. The flavor is chocolate and toffee with a sour earthy and bitter finish. Lots of smoke. Thanks Bill.

Bottle from E. Shared at SL. Thanks brother. Black in color, nice head that faded quickly. Smokey aroma plus smoked sausage. Taste is right with the nose. Campfire smoke, smoke sausage, balanced out with helping hand of roasted malts. Basically smokey as hell... Easy drinking. Overall...the best smoked beer I have had. Thanks again E

Deep, dark brown with a voluminous, dense, well formed foam.  The aroma is of bacon on a charcoal grill. Mmmmm.  A hint of applewood smoke and cocoa powder provide the flavor with a well balancing hop dryness in the finish.  This is a very smooth, solid, smoked porter.

UPDATED: FEB 26, 2010 pitch dark, small thick light brown head 
aroma is toffee, smokey, roastyed malts, smoked grains, 
flavor : well balanced, roasted malt, smoked somthing, too much tooffee
Pours a very dark brown with a fat brown head. The nose is smoke, bacon, and some roasted malts.  Comes across the palate as a barbecue style smoke with a good amount of hop bitterness in the finish.

UPDATED: APR 3, 2009 Bottle. Pours a very dark brown with a fat brown head. Aroma heavy on the smoke with some roasted malt and hop to round it off. Taste initially is nice and smokey then progresses into a lingering hoppy finish. I really liked this one. I was just slightly disappointed the smoky flavor wasnt more pronounced. I will give it another shot though.
I really like smoked beers now.  Pours dark brown with a thick tan head.  Heavy smoke aroma, sort of like BBQ.  Great smoke flavor, I liked it and will try it again.  Good stuff.

UPDATED: FEB 14, 2017 650 ml bottle courtesy of sparky27. 2008 on the bottle. This beer pours a murky dark brown color with a big khaki head that has great retention and crazy lacing. The aroma is big and bold with smoked kielbasa and bacon. The flavor is liquid BBQ a good malt backbone and a touch of biter hops adding nice complexity. The finish is long with lingering smoky meats and bitter walnuts. The mouthfeel is full and malty, with just a little bit of grit. Overall: wow great beer, on par with the schlenkerlas (sp?) thanks for chance to try this one. Re-rate on 14 Feb 2017. Comments on tasting are unchanged, but Im upping my score a bit. Not nearly as smokey as I recall, but there are a lot of complex subtleties at play  This is simply one of the best smoked beers made in the USA.

2008 vintage. Bottle conditioned. 22oz bottle served in a snifter. Poured a deep opaque black with a thick tan head. Lots of carbonation. Smokey nose with some smoked sausage. Some hops in the aroma as well. Lots of barbecue style smoke in the flavor. Pretty good amount of hop bitterness in the finish. Long lingering finish of smoke and drying hops. Some black patent malt comes out as it warms. Piney hops as well. I like a good smoked beer, and this was top notch.

Bottle pours black with tan head.  Aroma is smoke, bacon, and some roasted malt.  Medium heavy mouthfeel.  Flavor is more smoke, some chocolate, coffee, is creamy, and finishes with roasty smokiness.  A very nice brew.  One of the best smoke brews Ive tried.

Pours deep black into an English pint. Mocha head with excellent retention leaves spider lacing as it slowly recedes. Bacon and smoke aromas. Smooth with smoked bacon and malts.  Sweet, lasting alcohol finish.

Bottle, pours dark brown with a tan head and nice lacing. Some smoke but not as much as other brews I have tried. Good carbonation, nice dark malts add bitterness to the brew. No where near the smokiness of the alaskan smoked porter. Not a big ham sandwich but not bad.

Pours black with two fingers of tan head.  Aromas of strong malts and coffee.  Smell is very smokey with chocolate and dark fruit in the background.  Taste is sweet and smokey.  Fruity and chocolate notes and some nice malty flavor as well.  This is a very creamy, thick beer with a decent amount of carbonation.  This is a very good smoked porter.  I want some more.
From the tap poured dark brown with a small head.  Nice smoked malty flavor with a lasting finish.

Crushed with Jakebra.  On tap @ Left Hand.  Nice smoky aroma, but not much else.  Got some nice roast.  Flavor is almost the same.  Nothing fantastic here.  Finish gets a little sour for no real reason.  Its aight.  Not as good as advertised.

UPDATED: MAR 13, 2009 Tall inky head, holds for a bit..heavy smoke aroma with a hint of Chinese black tea and newly burnt alder. Big malt and smoke flavor with a whisper of cocoa sweetness.
Good goop if you like rauch/stout.

Had it on tap at Humpys a few days later and thought the bottle was much nicer.

Nice Brown/Tan Head not lasting. Good Lacing. Dark Brown to Black. Subtle scent of fruits and chocolate behind smokey aroma. Even some apple at the end. Very, very creamy! Still the subtle hint of fruits behind the smokiness.  Smokiness not as pronounced as in the aroma. Chocolate truffle with a hint of raspberry! Nice bitter hop finish. Peppery on the sides as if stuck in your teeth, while hops rest on the tongue. Lots of carbonation for a bigger beer.

Dark brown, almost opaque black in the glass, just a little bit of light is visible in the corners of the glass.  Poured with a large one-finger tan head, good and lasting lacing.  Aroma is very smoky, with a little bit of wood, grapefruit and plum odors.  Medium thick, velvety and rich body.  Big, complex malt flavor, it practically billows smoke, with plum, caramel, and some spicy notes.  Just a little bitterness in the aftertaste.
bottle thanks to blutt59.  poured black with a thin tan head.  aroma of smoke, jerky, and dark roasts.  flavor was smoke and meaty.  thin body and no carb with some dryness.

Bottled. 
Dark brown colour with solid head. Aroma is dominated by smoked sausage, there is also a hint of chocolate. The beer offers a big maltiness, in good companion with a solid, chewy carbonation. Theres the customary residual sweetness that might tone down the smoke in flavour, but it is there and nicely so. Good maltiness in flavour. It seems to be a bit more bitter than the average Baltic Porters. Smoke is solidly nice in the finish. Clean and flawless beer, and one of the best beers Ive had from this brewery.

good but simple old bbq pit smell ... great head, big and healthy, nice lacing too ... a nice bold beer, not overdone, very clean, abv is well worked in also ... i want a bbq samich to partner this beut of a smoked brew.. " i like that"  ... a nice beer, what a smoked beer that is pretty widely distributed should be like (better than stone smoked by a freakin mile) ... why is this not available in texas?

Bottle and draft at Capones. Poured a nice black body with good size head. aroma is smoke meats, chocolate and burnt hair. Flavor is chocolate, peaty, smoked meats. The flavor at first can be a little too aggressive but smooths out very well in the end. Nice cocoa finish to it.
Poured pitch black with a big foamy borwn head. Smoke and cocoa aroma. Big smokey malt taste. Dark chocolate accent. Bitterness becomes apparent halfway through the glass.

Bomber. Black/brown color with a nice mediumsized beige head. Aroma is some hops,smokey notes and some bbq meat. Taste is smoket with some bitterhoppy notes,chocolate, and some roasted malt. Not to overpowering on the palate. Finishes strong with lots of spicey notes and a balanced sweetness to it all.

750ml bottle, 2006 vintage.  Pours dark brown with a moderate tan head.  Nose is a powerful and inviting blend of meaty and campfire smoke; very nice.  Flavor is more hearty smoke, with some light chocolate and coffee.  This one is not shy about being all about the smoke, and that seems to work just fine.  Good stuff, but you better be in the mood for a lot of smoke; this ended up being a great choice for a cooler rainy evening.

Bottle thanks to blutt59. The smell is smoke, beef jerky, malts, bbq meats, and coffee,  The look is black with a decent tan head.  The taste is malts, smoke, coffee, roasty, chocolate.  Great smelling beer.
Below average smoked porter. Soy sauce is prevalent in taste and smell. I much prefer stone and east ends offerings.

UPDATED: OCT 11, 2012 First rating65 cl (bomber) bottle, from Systembolaget NordstanOn February 23, 2009BB 12-2010Labelled 9.9% ABVVery dark brown to black color, small brown head. Fruity, sweet, licorice, crusched white pepper, smoke and alcohol scent. Sweet, malty, grainy, smoke, licorice, alcohol taste. Long dry roasted and alcohol afteraste. Smooth mouthfeel, low bitterness.7/4/6/4/13=3.4RerateSampled at Rackhouse Pub, Denver CO, on October 10, 2012, during the event Colorado Rare Beer Tasting2008 aged bottleDark brown color, dark brown head. Sweet, malty scent. Sweet, dry, grainy taste. Medium mouthfeel, medium high bitterness.This has aged very well.9/4/9/3/18=4.3

Bottle (bomber) shared with gnoff & deft. Black with fluffy beige head. Smoked aroma with salmiak, along with alcohol, gunpowder, and some caramel. Medium bodied, medium carbonation. Dry and quite bitter.

Bottled. Pours out in a dark brown colour with a rich lasting pale brown foam. Smoke, crackers, ham, dark chocolate and anise in the aroma. Nearly full-bodied with notes of peat, smoked ham, salt, burnt malts and black unsweetened chocolate. Long salty and a bit tarry finish with notes of tobacco and burnt malts.m

Bottle. Black pour with lovely light brown head. Smoky charred wood, meaty notes, some smoked Gouda and definite hop presence on the nose and on the tongue. Bit of roast. And some chocolate and slight coffee. Thin palate. Really damn good.

22 oz bottle. Dirty old oil pour, descent dark tan head. Chocolate aromas, some understated roast. Starts a little creamy, but loses that and has a nice carbonated heavy-medium body. The taste is where the smoke shows up. Real nice balance of dark chocolate, roast malt, peat and coffee. More peat and coffee through the finish, which is a nice lingering roast. Very easy to down. This along with the Founders Porter are the best Ive had in a good eight months. The last, which I could compare this to is the Dark Horse Black Bier, which some would not classify as a porter. This is deserving of the rating. All the benefits of a Baltic, without some of the drawbacks that can pop up.
user_location: from Michigan now in Charlotte, North Carolina, USA

text: (22oz bottle, courtesy of blutt59)  Pours a dark brown body with a small beige head.  Aroma of smoked jerky, freshly ground coarse peppercorn medley, roasted malt, and chocolate.  Flavor of smoked meat, roasted malt, some dark fruit, and light chocolate with a dry finish.  Excellent smoked beer!

Draught, Oldsmar Tap HouseNear black.  Thick light brown head.  Smokey, meaty aroma with rich chocolate malt and a slight dark fruit note.  Rich dark malts, molasses & dark fruits with just a sick amount of smoke piled on top of that.

Bottle thanks to blutt59. Pours a black brown color. with a small canvas colored head. Some lacing. Notes of bacon fat, chocolate, smoke, burnt wood from a bonfire, sand (beach), and maybe some imagined maritime salty sea air. Medium mouthfeel and longer finish. This is the most drinkable smoked I have had and it is damn good.
Bottle thanks to blutt59. Black in color with a good sized tan head. aroma is of smake, roasted malt and coffee. Taste is of black pepper, roasted malt, smoke, a little wood, coffee, and chocolate.
bottle, black coloerd pour with no head, love the meaty smoke aromas, coffee, brisket, black pepper flavors, good finish

UPDATED: FEB 22, 2009 Draught, Oldsmar. Opaque black with tan head. Bamberg-esque intensely smoked aroma is gorgeous. Smooth carbonation is soft, creamy, and velvety mouthfeel. Flavors are awesome. A heavily smoked foreground on a background of fruity malt that is slightly sweet. Super impressed by how they nailed the big malts into an excellent rauchbier.

UPDATED: SEP 9, 2009 650 ml. No abv on label, but says "2008 bottle conditioned". Pitch black with a lasting quarter-inch of creamy foam. Aroma is hickory-smoked molasses and country ham with some sea breeze. Taste is the smoky-sweet hickory, molasses, caramel, and coffee drippings that were used to fry/saute country ham. Some light dabs of milk chocolate. Medium-heavy body is smoothly carbonated, just watery enough to be drinkable and just sticky enough to be a delicious and dangerous dessert. Nicely dried by the smoke and roast. Frosty lacing left everywhere.

Poured into a Sam Adams lager glass.  Big dark tan to light brown head and a nearly black body with the smallest hint of translucency when held to a light.  Aroma after letting it warm up a bit was initially fairly hoppy, with decent smoke and some chocolate as well.  Being a malt man the hop aroma led me to taste with some trepidation.  However, the hop bitterness perfectly complimented the spicy smokiness.  I loved just holding this beer in the front of my mouth and exhaling.  The smoke and bitterness hit the back of your tongue while the body does its work up front for a spicy and yet creamy feeling.  Hence the 5 for palate.  Ill enjoy this beer for a good long night.

Really impressed. Not a fan of smoked beers but this was really good. Smokey aroma is intriguing instead of off-putting. Almost completely black with a thick tan head. Probably recommend splitting the bottle due to the fact that its almost 10% and a sipping beer in my opinion. Good job Left Hand.

Bottle thanks to blutt59. Pours with a light brown head over a near black body. Aroma is smoke, with jerky, some artificial smoke, meat and wood. Taste is beef, chocolate, smoke and pepper. Syrupy mouthfeel with light bubbles. I am not a big smoked beer fan, but this one has its merits.

Bottle thanks to blutt59. Pours a dark, deep brown with a tan head. Aroma of smoked jerky and pepper, YUM!!! Flavor is very much the same. Mouthfeel is full body with high carbonation. Overall, this beer made me very hungry!!!!
Bottle.  Pours dark brown/black with a decent dark tan head. Aroma: bitter chocolate with smokey overtone Flavor: chocolate and toffee flavors with some woodfire smoke. NIce Smoked Porter!
UPDATED: JAN 1, 2014 TAP: at the Happy Gnome (St. Paul, MN) on 2.14.09. Jet black pour, moderate head. Strong aroma and taste of smoke and beef jerky, borderline overwhelming. Pretty good beer.

Finally purchased this one.  Ive generally been tenative when purchasing smoked beers.  Ive always found them intriging, but, it has been an evolution, essentially an acquired taste.  This baby comes in at almost 10%; making me wonder how smoky it could be.  Challenge accepted.  This is an excellent porter.  The smoke is not overwhelming, but IMO adds to the mystique of this beer.  Nice bbq type flavor which accents the cocoa, slight coffee, and some earthy hops.  This is what Id call a winner.  Without a doubt one of Left Hands best brews.

300th rating! Black pour with brown-white head. Aroma of roasted malt with a backbone of subtle smokiness. Flavor is at once smoky and roasty. Hints of coffee and bitter chocolate, but the smoke is always there. Finish is bitter and not overly dry. I enjoy the smoky aroma (it goes well with the roasted character of a porter) but Im not sure about the smoke flavor after awhile. Its never overpowering in any one sip, but over time it becomes a bit much. A very nice beer, but Smoked is not really my style.

Nice beer.  The first thing that you notice upon crackin this beast is a hefty, smoky sweet aroma that is sharp and ever present yet refined.  Up close the smell of cured ham comes through, very neat.  The flavor is a different story.  It is slightly overdone toward the smoky end, but not enough to upset the apple cart because other than the smoke, your also getting a nice dose of espresso and molasses.  The mouthfeel seals the deal with me.  For a porter this must be called full bodied and supple.  Glides across the whole mouth leaving a stickiness afterwords.  Nice Job Stranger. 2008 22 oz.

2008 22 oz. bottle from Plaza Liquors - Pours a clear brown color with a large two finger thick tan head.   Light waves of lacing.  Aroma is primarily smoked malt.   Flavor is mostly smoked malt with lightly sweetened roasted malt.  Finish is bitter and dry.  Medium to full body.  Nice!

Wow! Pours as black as a smoky, moonless night!! And the taste.... its like drinking a combination of hickory smoked bacon and Neuhaus bittersweet chocolate, while working forest land fire suppression, for the BLM, in the middle of August! Smoke-tacular!!

On draft at redlight. Pours a very dark brown almost black body with a dense, tan head that shows good retention. THe aroma is big on the smoked chocolate malt and peat malt, smokey meat, toasted caramel, and hints of cream. The flavor is very balanced with a good amount of smoke, roast and bitterness to go with the dark chocolate and sweet caramel in the background. The smoke in noticleable throughout and adds depth. Smoked meat flavors come through as well with the roasted bitterness. The body is full and smooth on the palate with moderate carbonation. Nioce and easy drinking with a long and roasty finish. Perfect beer for a bbq. An awesome smoked porter.

Bomber and on tap @ redlight redlight, both fresh. Pours black, no light getting through, a dark brown one finger head, nice lacing and retention. Just wonderful smoke, campfire and chocolate, some caramel. Flavor is well-balance with smoke and chocolaty roast, a medium caramel sweetness tempered by the slight acidity from the smoke, slight salty earthy hints. Not trace of the ABV. Very velvety in the mouth. A joy to drink.

Bottle from Ed at Heritage.  Reminds me of the fatherland.  Pours charcoal from the bomber with a brown head.   Smells of toasted malts and peat.  Tastes a lot like Schlenkerla, which is to say liquid meat and blood, with a note of bakers cocoa.  Theres something savage about this beer that really makes it amazing.
A very tasty smoked imperial porter on draft.  Just a 2 oz sample, but the flavors of chocolate and smokey wood were evident.

Draft @ Redlight Redlight, 2nd beer in a Smoked horizontal. Deep brown color with a rich head and heavy lacing. Earthy campfire smokiness. Notes of chocolate. Flavor brings a decidedly smoky and meaty flavor with the most amazing notes of a salty minerally bleu cheese. Really it became a liquid bleu cheese. Simply amazing funkiness. Freaky awesome. I have never encountered anything like that in a beer.

22oz bottle.  Darkest brown in color with a medium beige head.  Nose consists of some malt, but mostly smoked ham.  Flavor is more like honeybaked ham because of the malty sweetness.  Decent for the style.

Thanks to JaBier for sharing a bottle. This beer pours a solid black color with a thin and compact tan head that diminishes slowly. Thin rings of lacing on the glass. Smoked ham aroma with some dark malt and wood in the background. Medium-bodied with a strong smoked character and flavors of burnt wood, malt and hops. The finish is smokey and malty with a light alcohol and hops aftertaste. Overall this is a decent beer, however it veers a little too far on the smoky side for my tastes.

A rich smoky aroma. Great black color, full tan head. To be honest, I did not expect this. I am surprised by how smoky this was and also how greatly flavorful. Some graininess in the finish. I found this to be a truly excellent beer.

good porter. The smokeyness is a bit understated, and truth be told a bit weak. however I am not trying to paint the image that this a mediocre beer at all. This is a very good porter, drinks smooth and as I always appreciate, is smooth for a 10% abv. Gotta love it when they go down smooth and mess you up twice as fast. I was highly anticipating trying this beer and it may have gotten me a bit to hyped up. I would drink this again but I wouldnt say it would be my first choice

What a behemoth this turned out to be.  The aroma wafting off the glass reminded me of the scent of burning evergreen limbs in the backyard - not simply woody smoke, but a pronounced fresh-but wood component intertwined.  Great roasted malt backbone that is highlighted with some caramel sweetness, fresh honey, beef-jerky-hickory and spice, and a rich peaty moss earthiness.  One helluva drink.

Nice aroma of smoked malt and underlying imperial porter base smells such as strong chocolate and roast, also some alcohol notes as well. Pours dark brown with some dark red hues and a mousy brown head that settles to almost nothing. Nice smoked malts up front. Salt and barbecue, roast follows, dark bitter chocolate, and some strong alcohol warmth come through. Definitely smokey and sticky mouth feel. Pretty strong alcohol too. Good.

Served on draft as part of the Black Moonday event at Capital Alehouse in Richmond, VA. Pours a dark brown color with a small head and average head retention. Aroma is smoke, leather and mint. Taste is smoke and minty hops. Full bodied and slightly sticky.

Bottle.  Pours a thick and dark brown with a small and slow-forming head.  Aromas are sweet with a touch of smoke... almost a brown sugar sweetness and a peat and woodsmoke smokiness.  I expected the aromas to be a bit more pronounced.  A bit of a vinous quality and chocolate to the nose as well.  Flavor is a pleasant mix of peat, charcoal and bacon-which is the most pronounced of the smoke flavors until the very end of the finish.  The sweetness from the malt is a little overbearing at times... a brown sugar, fig/prune and mild chocolate presence there.  This is pretty good, but I expected a little more from it.
user_location: The Wet Side of a Dry Town, Pennsylvania, USA

text: Dark roast malt and lovely overtones or beechwood and thick, viscous campfire smoke.  Pitch pour with a dark brown head and little legs and lace.  Chocolate and smoke taste, porter aspects come forward and dominate the main.  Alcohol showing, feeling 9-10%, medium body and very warm.  Overall, a definite disappointment considering the score here - but definitely worth a go, if you can get a good deal.

22 oz. bottle courtesy of a trade with Cliff.  Pours black with a thin-moderate dense brown head that lasted beyond mid-glass and laced the glass well.  Very pleasant aroma of smoke.  The smoke is definitely more of a smoked meat fragrance as opposed to wood smoke.  The flavor is roasted malt and smoke (again, the meat variety).  Fairly smooth at the finish.  Full bodied and rich.  A top notch smoked beer.

UPDATED: FEB 11, 2010 Black with a brown head. Big smoky meaty aromas. Smooth, full body with soft carbonation. Very good chewy, charred malt flavors with hickory smoked bacon and eggs. Light booziness in the finish. Fucking great smoke brew here.
user_location: Same Trailer, Different Park, Louisiana, USA

text: On tap at Oldsmar Tap House (Tampa, FL). Pours a dark black color with thin tan head. Aroma is smoky, roasted and malty with notes of ripe dark fruit, dark chocolate, strong overtones of campfire. Flavor is generally roasted, malty and smoky as well with dark chocolate, ripe dark fruit, honey and caramel sweetness, and hints of spice. Generally medium to full body with a pleasing smoky and malty finish. Some and campfire notes are evident early in the glass but seemed to mellow as the beer warmed.

Poured at Jupiter brewfest.  Finally I get to try this beer!  Black pour with a tan head.  Aroma has some great smoke,  dark malts and woodsy notes.  Flavor hits wtih smoke, but it isnt overdone.  It is prominent, but yo gte beer flavor, fruity flavors and more that allowed this beer to really shine.

A very large light brown head topped a nearly perfectly black body. The aroma was decently smoked with some fruit wood and biscuits. There is a little bit of caramel character. The taste has some lightly smoked pancakes and hints of caramel. The woody finish shares itself with some light peach candy. This is nicely done and relatively subtly smoked.

Pour is a pitch black with a small tan head.  Aroma is smoke with some meatyness.  Flavor is again smoke with some bacon and roasted ham.  Im not a fan of smoked beers but they did hit the mark on the head with this one. But this is another beer that should not be in a 22 bottle as you could only take a small sample in a sitting.

Color is a solid black with good carbonation and a big thick tight tan head.  Aroma is deep and smoky.  Taste is rich and smoky.  Starting with a medium body it goes down with a crisp sharp feel.  Finish comes in sweet with a rich feel then a big bold smoke taste with deep roasted coffee flavors and a touch of bitterness.  After taste is a lingering smoke taste with a hint of alcohol.  This is a tasty and complex brew, the palate is a bit sharp at first but seems to smooth out as you drink it.
which in smoke flavor, taste is very smokey and some dark malts. hops are very apparant with a bit of pine. flavorful and strong. quite good.

The aroma is as billed with lots of smoke and malt but nothing else. The appearance is almost black (brown) with a nice tan head. The flavor is like the aroma. The palate is smooth. Overall its exactly what most lovers of smoke want but I dont like smoke beer.
Intense smoke reminds me of hazelnut smoked cheese.  Dark brown, almost oily with a sandy head.  Loads of smoke, one sided and covers up any subtlety, but great smoke flavor.
Very dark pour with a nice bit of beige head.  Medium smokey aroma.  Rich malt flavor up front with a lingering, elegant smokey aftertaste.  Just the right amount of smoke.

On tap at Stub and Herbs, Minneapolis.  Dark pour with not much head.  Aroma of chocolate and strong roasted malts.  Not as much smoke as I had anticipated.  Silky smooth body.  More smoke in the flavor then on the nose.  Some sweetness of chocolate and soda mixed with roasted malts.

Draft at Kumas. Pour is a nice dark chocolate brown. Super smokey aroma that absolutely carries into the flavor. It had a lot of sweetness to it as well. It was kind of like drinking a polish sausage...which was a bit weird and awesome at the same time.

Bomber, 2008.  Pours brown/black with low apparent carbonation and just a trace of a tan head.  Aroma shows intense smoke.  Chocolate notes linger in the background but this one is mostly pure smoke - in a good way.  Probably the best pure smoke aroma Ive encountered thus far in commercial beers.  Flavor is full bodied, malty, chocolately with a beautiful smoked finish.  Not overly phenolic.  Smooth, creamy, almost silky mouthfeel.  No astringency.  This is very impressive and certainly the best smoked beer Ive had, and Im a huge fan of this style.  I wish this were a year round beer.

Tap at Kumas. Pours a deep, dark black-brown with dissipating head. Nose sweet and touch acidic, roasty with a nutty smoked ham smell. Taste is different for a smoked beer. Due to the abv, it comes across as being a rather sweet beer. Not enough smoke flavor, not nearly robust enough to be rated where it is, however it is a pretty drinkable beer, but the alcohol makes it a bit thin and is missing some body. Pretty decent, but certainly not better than the Schlenkerlas...

Penetrable black chestnut. Thin but creamy and semi-rocky grayish foam. Enticing marriage of beefy yet refined smoke laced with sharp notes of cola, roasted barley (creamed coffee), and charcoal. Hints of nougat, toasted bread, licorice, and an uplifting combination of airy and dried plum esters. Yeast lends an ever faint suggestion of taffy. Expressive carbonation provides for a lively mouthfeel. Bottle conditioned. Briskly chalky, sharp, and dryly roasty, initially, yet densely layered with soft but assertive rauch malt swirled with rich chocolate truffles which swiftly emerge amid the dryness. Malt character is clean and layered beautifully, yielding a charcoal and bittersweet chocolate snap atop a bready and smoky cushion. The cleanness is slightly hampered by some weighty slickness reminiscent of cola-flavored candy and meaty molasses at the bodys core. Still, the savory interplay between the dense chocolate, roasted malt hulls and chalky dryness abbreviates much of this. Black licorice and plummy esters lend complementary effect as they lurk in the background. A metallic and plumlike twang precedes an ensuing smidge of tobacco, salted licorice and smoky phenolics in the finish. A quality, "best of both worlds" kind of beer.

text: 22oz Bomber  99 Bottles  Federal Way, WA  This is a smoked porter with a huge Smokey flavor.  The beer has great malt build and the dark grains where toasted with the right amount of added peat.  A super beer.

2008. Pours a nice thick dark black that allows some light. Head is two fingers, dark mocha. The nose has an upfront smoke character, more of a sweet smoke than a meaty one. Some coffee and chocolate, a little roasty. Nice pungent nose with a good smoke balance. Flavor is a bit of a stepdown. Smoke character is there in balance. Base porter seems strong, very robust. The bitterness from the grains and hops seems to detract. Some coffee and bakers chocolate. Flavor has a nice thick consistency with a filling carbonation, bitter/astringent feel from the grains. Alcohol well hidden throughout. Definitely tasty but not the best.

22oz bomber.  2008 Vintage.  Pours black with a big dark tan head.  Head is long lasting, and leaves behind some great lacing.  Aromas of smoke, smoked meat, pork, bacon, caramel, liquid smoke and some roasted malts.  Flavors are exactly the same, this is a meal in a bottle.  A nice semi sweet entry with a bitter finish.  Full bodied and good.

Pours a dark opaque brown with a thick rich light chocolate head.  Delicious smokey aroma along with notes of toasted malt.  Smooth creamy rich flavor of chocolate, espresso and caramel.  Very little bitterness; definitely in the porter style verses that of a stout.  Alcohol is well muted.
Very dark smoked beer. Reminded me a lot of the schrenkla rauch. black and meaty, heavily smoked.

Sampled on draft at the Oldsmar Taphouse. 
Dark as night. Smoky as a campfire. Warming, velvety, hints of chocolate and toffee. This is Absolutely Outstanding! An awesome beer, complex and round; fully worthy of  a large extent of praise!

On tap at The Stable.  A beautiful black pour with a big thick frothy head.  Smoke was in the aroma along with chocolate and coffee. Flavor is the same with coffee and chocolate dominating.  These flavors seemed to alternate with each sip and smoke was a steady undertone.  Alcohol was not really tasted but felt.  A wonderful beer from first sip to the bottom of the glass.

UPDATED: JAN 10, 2009 bomber.  no light is allowed to pass through this solid black brew. a smallish khaki colored head recedes leaving some thick lacing. mostly smokey char on the nose. some dark malts and tar also appear alongside a hint of tobacco. layers of smoke are well balanced by roasty malt and a fine amount of bitterness. dark chocolate and vanilla fudge hide behind charcoal then reappear on the finish. the palate is thick and sappy, perhaps a little too heavy..  as i have noticed with other rauchbiers, it takes a few sips to notice anything other than the smoke.  Hiden underneath is a rich, well structured delight that should be served closer to warm to enjoy all the flavors. fans of this should seek out ofallon brewerys  smoked porter.

Bottle.  Pours dark brown with a frothy medium sized head.  Smoked meats and roasted barley with a hint of sweetness in the nose.  Flavors of barbeque meats, dark roasted coffee, hops, and smoke with a touch of molasses.  Very smooth for a smoke beer, excellent balance and very enjoyable.  Would be an excellent introduction for someone who has never had a rauchbier.  Good stuff.

Draft at Jerrys. Black with big, foamy chocolate shake head / Nose of roast barley, chocolate and smoke / Medium to full body, good balance of malt and hops, with long, dry finish / Flavors of bittersweet chocolate, dark roast coffee, salami, and smoke, with some citrus notes / The complexity and balance supported by the subtle use of smoke make this the best smoked beer Ive ever had, but then I find most Rauchbiers overbearing and dreadful.

Bomber brought back from the desert by footbalm, thanks man. Pours a dark brown color with a nice medium light brown head. The aroma is powerful; smoked beef jerky, some earth and caramel. The flavor was initially simply smoke, and tons of it, meaty and awesome. As you get used to the smoke a strong caramel and earthy malt kicks in, there is even some light hops in the finish. However, in the end, this tastes like smoked meat, and I love me some nice smoked jerky! Excellent.

Pours an oily black colour with an epicly dense tan head that never fades and clings to the glass. The nose is dustly, medium smokey, and meaty with sweet roasted malts. As far as the taste, whew! This is the smokiest beer Ive come across. I mean campfire smokey. There are some piney, citric hops, beef jerky, malt sweetness, corn syrup and some dark, dried fruits. The palate is silky smooth, full-bodied and and long lasting. EPIC

Dark brown pour with thick chestnut colored head and honey comb lace.  Smoked sausage aroma.  Medium bodied. Caramel, roast, coffee, and smoke.  Twist of hops on a dry finish.  This has to be the best beer made by LH

Tap OTH.
Pours blakc brown with brown head.
Aroma is very smokey, bacon like smoked pork. with a faint roasted coffee, caramel malts.
Taste is once gain loaded with smoke, light malts. Overall mouthfeel is smokey followed by a near dark fruit palate.
With gained ambient temperature, the malts became more prominent while smoke was attenuated.
Overall finish has some light hops with present caramel malts and warming abv.
A lightly higher version of the smoked Goosinator.

750ml bottle via trade.  Pours a deep brown with a faint ruby hue.  A small beige ring for a head.  Big nose of smoked meat and some dried pit fruits.  Flavor is also very smokey with the finish being very thick and chewy, a great rep of the style.

Very good beer...more aggressive rauchbier quality than its cousin Alaskan Smoked Porter.  2008 bomber exhibited an extremely dark mahogany with a dense 2 finger cocoa colored head that has tremendous lasting power.  Aroma is bitter chocolate, fresh coffee, and dark roasted malts, followed by tremendous smokey BBQ characteristics.  Flavor also is aggressive pulled pork sandwich, along with molasses, caramel, and toffee.  Thick, luscious mouthfeel.  WOW!!!
740 ml bottle shared with neighbors.  Lots of malty dark aromas off this black beer with decent head.  Burnt malts and touches of smoke.  Not as smokey as I had expected, but very very good

Fresh 2008 bomber.  Pouring an extremely dark chocolate brown color, the substantial body is crowned with a lasting, dense, creamy tan head.  Robust scents of roasted chocolate malts, smoked pork shoulder, worn leather, and scorched caramel are brought together by hints of smooth, lactic cream.  The flavors are well balanced, with considerable roasty and bitter notes being balanced by semi-sweet chocolate and dark caramel.  Hefty smoke permeates all, instilling a leathery, earthy, meaty feel to the beer.  The smooth, substantial body is moderately carbonated, almost silky on the tongue.  This is a great beer.  It reminds me of an imperial version of Alaskan’s famous smoked porter.
Pours a nice dark brown/black with a decent dark tan head. Nice smokey chocolate nose. Nice chocolate and toffee flavors through with smokiness on the finish.

Not surprisingly,this smells smokey.  Maybe a hint of caramel malt there, but really its just smokey.  Pour is black with a thick creamy head.  The flavor matches, creamy yet dry and chalky.  The slight dry chocolate flavor is thin, and really smothered by the smokey flavor.  Lord, I wish I had a thick fire licked stead right now.

Bottle at Eulogy, Philadelphia, with Traci, Fin & Loz. Brown/black, good tan head. Big smokey cheese nose, slighty damp birchwood campfire, vanilla. Sweet mineral smoke flavor that feels very well-integrated with the roasty chocolate flavors. Very smokey, but balanced. It feels like with some smoked beers, the smoke tastes like an afterthought to an existing beer. This tastes like it was created with smoke in mind. Good beer.

One of my most sought after beers since Ive become a smoke fan. Aroma was near perfect. Strong smoke flavor with some chocolate in the background. Pour was a nice deep dark brown/near black with a one finger tan head. Taste didnt disappoint. Strong smoke flavor which gives way to some chocolate as it warms. I love this style when the smoke dominates and just passively allows other flavors to come through in the aftertaste. Great beer!

text: WOW!!! smoke Smoke and more Smoke dark dark brown pour. big foam. nose is guess what..... smoke. big charred aroma, like im at a campfire. kinda sweet malts flavor but big alcohol and big smoke. can see lotsa talent in brewing this and it is an interesting beer but its TOO much for me..
Bottle.  Pours a dark brown body with a tan head.  Big smoke, campfire, roasted meat and malt nose.  Char and woodiness with a nice alcohol warming. Big freakin fan of this one.

Draft, served in a small tulip glass.  Pours a dark brown body with tan head.  Aroma of smoked meat with hints of roasted malts and chocolate.  Flavor is mostly the same, initially tasting like smoked ham and then the malts, cocoa, and coffee flavors come out more as you drink it.

Bottle at Eulogy, Philadelphia, in the company of Loz, Casey and Traci on my fortieth birthday, 16-11-08. Pours black, brown head. A stunning beer, quite unusual with an almost cheesy feel to it at times, maybe that smoked processed stuff? Quite roasty, little furry feeling in the mouth, there is a slight Schlerlenka feel to this at times, and thats a big compliment. Smokiness continues throughout and this is a very nice beer. A7   A4   F8   P4   OV16     3.9

Draught at Akkurat, Stockholm. Dark reddish brown color with tan head. Sweet, smoky, earthy and leathery aroma. Bittersweet flavor with firm roastiness, strong earthy-leathery smokiness as well as notes of coffee and licorice. Tarry, earthy and smoky  finish. Very robust smoke beer.

750ml - Aroma is very smokey.  Salty meat, burnt malts and some chocolate.  Pours black with a huge brown fluffy head and great lacing.  Flavor is campfire, burnt malts, coffee, crispy bacon, chocolate and a touch of hops.  Palate is creamy and dry.  Not for the faint of heart, this beer has teeth.  I like it.
