Bottle.  Poured a dark black with a thin tan head.  Aroma of smoke with roasted malt and coffee notes.  Flavor is meaty.  Medium body with mild carbonation.

Corked and caged 750ml courtesy of RustyChiles.  Pours a pitch black with a half finger tan head and spotty lacing.  Nose is very smoky.  It has a smoked meat smell to it which is cool.  Some burnt malt and coffee going on too.  Taste is smoked bacon, baby back ribs with sauce, burnt dark chocolate and campfire coffee.  Medium creamy mouth feel.  I like it  not as much as the Alaskan Smoked Porter, but its still a good smoked.  Thanks Rusty!

UPDATED: NOV 13, 2010 (Draught at Akkurat, Stockholm, 15 Sep 2008) Black colour with ruby light when seen through light. Frothy, pale brown head. Malty, roasted nose witn distinct notes of smoke. Malty, roasted taste with chocolate, dark fruit, dark rye bread, nuts and a dry smokey finish. Smoke dominates the aroma more than the flavour, that is more complex. Medium to full body, smooth mouthfeel. Mainly dry. Alcohol hardly evident at all. Lovely beer! (8/4/7/4/15=3.8) Rerate: (bottle, 13 Nov 2010) Very dark brown colour, almost black, with creamy beige head. Malty, smoky nose with notes of roasted malt, smoke, coffee, liquorice, dark rye bread and cocoa. Malty, roasted taste with black coffee, smoke, liquorice, dark bread and cocoa. Warming, slightly vinous finish with balanced notes of coffee bitterness. Almost full body, smooth and almost creamy mouthfeel. Excellent balance. Lovely porter with a subtle smoke character.

OK, this is a really, really hard one for me to rate. This beer is awesome, f’n delicious in every way. Nice and creamy, great soft texture and creamy mouthfeel. Looks great, pours a nice, even dark brown. Smells like smoked meat and candy. So, why is it so hard to rate? Well, I thought the smoke was almost lacking. For me, this one is a little too balanced. I expected big time smokiness. I expected big time meat flavor. I expected Goosinator on Crack, but this is a totally different beer. Smokejumper relies more on the malt backbone and shows off its deep flavor instead of letting the smoke become the flavor. Weaker on smoke, but a homerun on balance and flavor complexity.

750 ml bottle shared at BCTC 2008. Poured a deep dark brown with a medium sized frothy light beige head. Aroma of smoke, roasted malts, chocolate and some anise. Palate on this one was simply awesome, thick, chewy with an oily base and average carbonation, NICE!!! Flavor has lots of smoke on the aftertaste but starts off with some notes of toast and chocolate. This was one great beer and I’m kicking myself for not picking some up when I saw it around.

Pours black with topping creamy head.  Smokey aroma with licorice.  Above average mouthfeel, even thick in the mouth.  A very good example of its style. Good roasted chocolate malt, salty. Drinkable with lunch yet it does overwhelm tastes.A man’s beer.

Pours an almost opaque black with a big, tan head. Aroma is chocolate and smoked meats, campfire. Tastes kind of like bacon, which is awesome, and chocolate, with a slight alcohol burn. There’s also some caramel and tobacco. Mouthfeel is smooth, and thick for a porter. A little bit of hops in an otherwise long finish, and overall an awesome ale. If you see this, you should get this.

UPDATED: DEC 10, 2009 [rated 6.25.08] Pours near black with a thin creamy beige head. Smokey bacon aroma with some dark malts and a little bit of funky fridge aroma.  Amazing flavor, smoke followed by chocolate... fantastic... then bacon and dark chocolate in perfect balance, some wood and residual sugars.  Silky smooth carbonation, perfectly creamy, slight syrup, medium full body.  More please.  8.4.9.5.18 . . . . . . . . . . . . . . . . . . . . .  [ rerate 2009 bottle December 2009 8.4.8.4.16]

750ml bottle from 2006. Pours a deep brown, but lets a little light through when in the glass.  Small head. Aroma was very smoky on top of a roasted malt/chocolate porter base. Smoke flavor was more wood s than meat.

UPDATED: JUN 11, 2008 2006 bottle.  Pours a deep black with a medium bubbly tan head.  Aroma of smoked salmon, chocolate, tobacco, woody, carame and creamy fudge.  Flavor of hot fudge, smoke meats, toffee, caramel, chocolate, nuts, nice and smooth, earthy, tobacco and light vanilla.

Thanks to 17thfkloor for sharing this one. Dark black pour with thin off white head. Aroma is bacon and chocolate all the way. Flavor is much the same, smooth roasty malts, bitter chocolate, and a nice big bacon flavor all blend well. Alcohol is well hidden. Definately would drink this one again.

UPDATED: JAN 4, 2009 EDIT:

I rated this two years ago when it was last out, and admittedly was farily new to smoke beers. This 2008 version is F’in Good and smokey as all get out!  Kick ass beer!  Going to buy several more bottles on monday!







nice smoked brew. not the best ive had but respectable. Nice smoked salmon and maple bacon aroma. good cloudy color. needs a little more smoke to be great. It was really smooth for 10 percent though. will try again!

750 ml bomber. Corked and caged.  Pours a deep, deep brown. Appears black until you hold it up to the light. Small off white head with no lace to speak of. Nose is smoky (duh), with roasted malt and bakers chocolate.  Dry mouthfeel with low carbonation.  Taste is same as nose & Ill agree with the majority of other raters in saying that the smoke was not overwhelming. Very good brew.

750 bomber courtesy of Maniac. 
Coffee, toffee and smoke dominate aroma. Color is very dark almost black with almost no head. Raisin and rum soaked fruit with roast and smoked malt flavors.Noteable hop bitterness and smoke in the finish. Medium body mouthfeel with moderate astringent bitterness. Well smoked and could easilly have been an Imperial Stout if it wasnt so dry. This one would go well with some BBQ.

Pour is black with a huge brown head...smell is richly roasty and darkly smokey...taste is thickly smoking throughout, with lots of richly roasty chocolate flavors...but some stupid piney hops come in during the finish that just wreck everything...

UPDATED: AUG 3, 2008 750 ml bottle 2006 vintage corked and caged, from a trade with hogtownharry. pours pitch black with a nice tan head. aromas are out of this world. mellow chocolate, chared oak barrel with sweet malts. this brew has the most complex aromas ive ever had. every waff shows a new level of goodness. flavours are equally impressive. beautiful sweet malts with chocolate and caramel. some bitterness kicks in to level it all out and then you get the smoke. oh man this is insanely good stuff! ill be sipping and savouring this one all night. oh my god i want more of this. its stupid good!
Bottle share by seaoflament @ Cuvee de Tomme release. (Thanks Carlos!) Great smokey smooth aroma and even better flavor of the same influences. The smoothest smoke I believe I have ever had.
Awesome porter from Left Hand!  Very dark, rich, and smoky with hints of chocolate and coffee... The smoke wasnt overpowering which was nice.  A sipper thats damn tasty!

Bottle from da east coast beer pimp, Immy.  Thank you kind sir!  The pour was ultra dark brown with slighter lighter hints trying to eek through.  A compact head, tan to brown in color, settled on top but failed to provide much in terms of lacing.  The aroma was rich smoked peat, light chocolate, roasted malt.  The flavor wasnt dominated by the smoke, rather complemented by it.  The smoke mixed with rich roasted malt and softer chocolate quite well.  Nice mouthfeel.

Very nice.  Opaque pour with some ruby highlights.  Small rapidly dissipating head.  Aroma is slight smoked roasted malt.  Taste is bitter, smokey, malty.  Alcohol is not readily evident.  Thanks mcox90.
Poured black with a small brown head. Aroma of smoked meat and chocolate. Beautiful. Lots of smoke flavors in this guy. I had 2 dinners tonight.

Bottle 2006, labelled as 9.2%. Dark black body with a small light brown head. Huge smoke aroma with some chocolate and roasted malt. Huge smoke flavor, blending into chocolate, toffee, and light roasted malt. Medium body with moderately low carbonation. Definitely lots of smoke, but not nearly as excessive as some others.

Thanks to terminus for sharing this one.  Pours dark brown with a light crimson hue and a dense light brown head.  The aroma is very smoky with only light meatiness to the smoke.  Unfortunately there is still some bbq sauce aspects along with peat.  Medium body with a decent amount of carbonation.  The flavor starts with smoked malt, ash, light char and some dark chocolate.  The finish adds some spice and some smoked woodiness.  This is not really my thing, but pretty good for the style.  The alcohol is nowhere to be found in the beer.
nice and smoky,but still had nice chocolate,and other flavors to balance it out.good stuff.

THIS SURE AINT KOSHER!  This brew is complex, smooth, and delicious.  Smoke is upfront and in your grill (for real!).  Aroma is smoke, chocolate, and coffee.  Taste is coffee, smoke, and a ham or rib flavor.  This Porter came right off the grill!  This is also probably the thickest "porter" I have had.  It clings to the palate and the taste lingers.  It takes a long while to get through this bomber because you want to sip on it and get all the flavors.  I shared this with two other people and we all gave it thumbs up. Alcohol flavor is non existent which is good.

2006 750ml bottle from Odeed; Nose of chocolate, coffee, and light smokiness; black with brown edges and a medium tan head; flavor has smoke, hop bitterness, chocolate, and some background grape-wine notes; finishes with a tiny bit of bitterness and smoke! Best smoked Ive had!

bottle...thanks to sprinkle for the hookup....pours dark brown with reddish brown edges. a significant light brown head topped this bad boy off..... aromas of smoke and chocolate malt in which the former takes hold and doesnt quite seem to let go..... flavors of smoke, roast, and chocolate malt qualities.  very smooth overall and the mouthfeel was fairly nice as well..... still not the biggest smoked fan and from what i can gather, i enjoyed NGs smoked from the porter a little bit more.....i think i enjoyed this more that my score indicates.  could be a 4 in my book.

Lots of smoke aroma to this, as you would expect. Not as smokey as the Urbock. Really smooth for almost 10%. Mostly tastes of coco, smoked ham and bacon. Not my fav. smoke, but still a pretty good one

Pours deep black/brown with a foamy brown head. Aromas of campfire, roasted malt, and beef jerky. Complex flavors of malt, chocolate, and smokeyness. Not my fav. porter out there, but not bad. Just a little too much smoke for my taste.
user_location: back in NJ!, New Jersey, USA

text: Opaque and inky chocolate black in the glass with a decadent tan crest lying on top. The aroma more than brings out the smoke. Its a prophetic pyromaniac in a glass.  An unflinching summer sun bakes dry leaves on charred shingles. Mocha chips lurk with scorched dark chocolate as smoky oils foil the sweeter aromatic tendencies to virtual bliss. A hint of fatty pepper ignites even further past the olfactory flame. Flavor yields a decadent chocolate morsel with a near melting truffle like center. Charred cinnamon comes in with the broiler along with cocoa and mocha bean grinds finding themselves near the lip of the foreman grill trap. An oily, smoky, medium molasses provides a sweet, slick thickening across the palate. Full bodied and one hundred percent balanced with the best levels of carbonation piped into a 750-ml. on the shelf. Hazelnuts and almond fudge meet a smoky applewood motif and molasses for a finish that came too soon to fathom.

What a great smoked porter! Full bodied, brown/black, smoky, roasty, malty. Would love to try this again with some ribs or bbq chicken. As good as it is the price is a little high. Even if it is better I dont know if its worth it when I can get 3 bottles of the Stone smoked for the same price. Nice bottle for the collection

750ml bottle dated 2006.

Pours a deep brownish black with a foamy brown head. WOW, I can smell the smoke in this one. Aroma is fantastic, smoke, chocolate, coffee and roasted malt. The flavor is unlike that of any other beer ive ever had. Huge Smokiness, BBQ, Bacon, chocolate, barley. That said it is difficult to drink more than 1 glass of this beer due to the smokiness, its a bit over the top. Really interesting beer, would be a good base for a smoky flavored cheese fondue, but not an everyday beer for me.

On draft at Capones.  Pours a cola black with a medium sized creamy beige head.  Lots of lacing.  Aroma of smoked meat, roasted malt and chocolate.  Taste of smoky roasted malt with a hint of chocolate.

I like the smoked beers and this was very good,the smoke flavor was present but not overwhelming like some and it was black with a nice tan head and a lot of roasty malts very enjoyable i would  drink again.CHEERS!
Draft. Black with frothy head. Nice roasted malt smoke aroma. Oliy looking brew. The taste was of smoke, deep roasted malt, and grezzy pork. Very nice.

Smoked beers are to me a bit of a novelty rather than an everyday beer or a product to be savored.  This beer is definitely an exception to that idea!  This beer is really a very good beer that happens to be smoky.

Appearance is a black body with a tan head.  The appearance of this beer is the most appealing of any smoked beer Ive ever seen; many other smoked beers have little head and this beer looks like any other good porter.  Aroma was smoky and roasty in equal proportions.  Flavor is lots of dry roastiness with a touch of smoke, and quite good.  Mouthfeel is smooth and good.

Id highly recommend this beer.

I got this bottle at Discount Liquor in Milwaukee, and Ill have it again.

Pours a dark brown color that sits with reddish highlights in the glass. Short-lived head of soapy tan foam that recedes to a light ring. The aroma is still big and smoky after a year or so. Assertive aroma of burning firewood/scorched carbon and salty bacon. Slight negative in that the smoke has a slight gassy/lighter fluid aroma. Fortunately the smoke does not entirely dominate, with bready malt and bittersweet baking chocolate. Nice roasted malt and bittersweet chocolate flavors. The smokiness is more subtle than in the aroma. Dry finish of baking chocolate. hops, and smoke. The body starts off smooth, but the carbonation builds and overwhelms the flavor at times. Nice, dry finish. Overall, a tasty porter accented with a nice aroma of smoke. Drinks deceptively smooth for 9.2%

Bottle, provided by Shing. Dark brown, almost black with a thick beige foamy head. Aroma of wood/oak, smoke and some pipe tobacco. Flavor has notes of chocolate, dark fruits, tobacco, brown sugar and molasses. Pretty sweet and flavorful - not a whole lot of bitterness. Medium bodied with lively carbonation.

750ml bottle.  9.2% 2006 vintage.  Bottle pours an opaque dark brown color with a medium brown head.  Aroma is toasted and roasted malts, oak, smoked woods.  Flavor is a creamy malt, with smoked woods, and the same roasted and toasted malts.  I was worried it would be too much like the Smoked Goosinator Doppelbock that I had had, but the "smoke" complemented the beer much better.

25.4 oz bottle, 2006.  Dark, but penetrable, brown with maroon edges and a smooth tan head.  Nose is fruit wood smoke layered over plums, prunes and malt.  Even with some age this is still quite bold.  Medium full body, coating with a tangy tingle.  Taste is chocolate and peanut with building grapefruit.  Ending a bit sharp with smoke.

Pours a clear dark brown color with a ring of offwhite head. Good aroma and flavor of smoked and roasted malt with a bitter finish. The body is light to medium with a liquorous texture and gentle carbonation.

750 ml corked and caged bottle. 2006 vintage. My bottle says 10.5% AbV. Poured a nearly opaque black color. Head was thick and light brown with good retention but minimal lacing. Chocolate dominated aroma with burnt toffee and subdued smoked malt. There was also a whiff of raisin. Delicately sweet on the tongue with distinct chocolatey malt and alcohol flavors. The flavor imparted by the smoked malt was subtle relative to German varieties, but was a nice accompaniment to the chocolate flavor and imparted some bitterness that tempered the sugars somewhat. Delicious beer.
Again not a big fan of smoked beers.  Although they look amazing in the glass, it is like sucking on a bottle of liquid smoke.  Not my thing.

Bottle:  The aroma is a big dose of smoked cheese with a solid chocolate presence as well.  It pours a dark brown with no transparency and a large creamy tan head that leaves behind nice sheets of lacing.  The flavor starts with a moderate dose of chocolate with hints of molasses.  The finish has light-moderate smoke with some light piney bitterness.  The smoke flavor is much lighter than expected based on the aroma.  Medium bodied with a soft mouthfeel.

UPDATED: JAN 15, 2008 22oz. bottle.  Thanks to Greg!  Massively smoky, ashy aroma, some roasty, coffeeish malts, huge and powerful with a sweet undercurrent.  Dark brown in color, bottle-conditioned so there is some sediment, head is fine and lasting.  Flavor contains an equally huge amount of smoke but it is infused with dark caramel sweetness and cocoa throughout, some mildly spicy hop tones to be found as well.  The blend of these attributes may not seem exceptional, but in conjunction with one another, this becomes something really special.  Smooth mouthfeel, low in effervescence, body is quite full, some mild warmth noted.  Really indulgent stuff here.  Wow.

750ml bomber
Pours nearly black with a huge brown head that takes forever to subside.  Aroma smells like you just poured a bottle of "Liquid Smoke" into a glass of beer.  Flavor is really smoky choco-coffee.  Smoky taste is really powerful.  Taste like that mouthful of smoke you get from the campfire.  Alcohol is fairly well masked.  (by the SMOKE!)  Not bad though

Big bottle pours red to black with a nice tan head and good lace that seems to go away after a few.  The aroma starts out smoke house bacon with a hint of malt and some hops make it through.  The flavor has mutilple components that dance all over the mouth.  You have a malty and slightly floral porter in there, but then the smoke comes through only to be followed by a chocolate linger that is really quite nice; perhaps a bit like Mexican Mole - a bit of a stretch, but it really reminds me of one of my favorite sauces.  The alcohol is nowhere to be tasted. The palate is mouth filling, but fresh enough for a nice mild carbonated finish.  I gotta say, this is good.  Id like this with a good steak on the grill.  After an hour or two of this, it is a bit like smoking a cigarette.  Perhaps a bit too much of a good thing.

Bottle from Crown #15 in Fishers, IN. Shared with most of the KC crew at Indras tasting 12/7/07. Pours black with a wispy tan ring around the glass that leaves behind patchy lace. Big, roasted, smoked malt that instantly makes me think of smoked beef brisket. Medium-bodied with a smoky dry finish, the flavor follows the nose with a big, sweet, smoked malt body and a lesser note of faint chocolate malt. This reminds me quite a bit of Alaskan Smoke Porter but with a fuller body. Overall, Id have to say that I prefer this beer, but at twice the cost, I would probably recommend the ASP to anyone that is looking to sample an exceptional smoke beer for the first time.

Poured from a 2006 vintage, caged and corked 750ml bottle and served in a snifter.  This beer poured an oily black with a huge head of tan foam that slowly faded down to a thin, lingering layer.  Heavy lace coated the entire glass.  The aroma of the beer was made up of charred malts, chocolate, coffee, and also a strong note of smoke that saturated the senses.  The flavor included notes of moderate smoke that coated the entire tongue and throat,  dark milk chocolate, and also burnt toast.  The mouthfeel was full-bodied and slightly slick with mild carbonation.  The smoke in this beer was used to enhance the other flavors, not overwhelm the entire drink.  The high ABV was totally hidden behind the smoke and chocolate, only evident by a light warming finish.   A very tasty creation!

22 oz. bottle shared by Gregis at the 12/7 tasting at Indras.  Pour is almost entirely black, with a quickly fading 1/2 inch tan head.  Aroma of fireplace smoke.  A very damp fireplace at that, really dense, and really nice.  Taste is big smokiness, real full of charred meat flavors.  Nice full porter body.  Really well done, thanks for sharing this one Greg!

2006 Bottle Conditioned 750ml. Pour is initially very active and bubbly, but quickly settles out into a silky black with a head of swirly mocha lace. Coasts the glass nicely. The aroma is a nice mix of deep peat smoke and chocolate.  The flavor begins with the smoke full and upfront on my tongue. As the flavors swirl and settle, I notice the chocolate more, but the finish come back smoky and a touch bitter. I cant taste any of the significant alcohol. This is really nice. 7/5/8/4/18

Bottled. Big, strong, smoky aroma, lightly roasty, balanced and clean. Smoke and beets in the flavor, not too complex but quite tasty and refined. Tough to find any real flaws in this beers. Very tasty.
2006. Thanks Greg. Black, bottle conditioned. Smokey, mildly hammy, aroma. Roasty, chocolate, ashy with a nice sweetness. Thick bodied. Nice.
Thanx to ElMatador for this.This was pretty good.Lots of porter characteristics with lots of smoke.Roastedness, chocolate and smokiness how can you beat it?
Bottle from my friend Kurt. Might be my fav from Left Hand. Tons of smoke for sure which is really what is supposed to have right? The flavor was very nice for a long time and I sipped and enjoyed.

Opaque black pour that easily excites a thick mocha colored head that leaves sticky patterns on the side of the glass as it slowly fades.
Coffee hits the nose first, but almost instantly, that aroma is completely overpowered by thick sweet smoke.
The flavor is lightly sweet with soft smokiness, burnt toast.
Smooth bodied and it hides its alcohol completely, although the warming effect tips you off soon enough.
Nice brew for a winter day.
bottle. it has a dark brown color with a large head. there is a very nice smoked aroma present. the taste is also smokey. it has greast roastyness.

Holy crap, it was actually on draft nearby!  I had a few glasses and greatly enjoyed it.  Darker color with a light head.  Aroma is thick and smoky with dark chocolate, burnt sugar, and plenty of smoky-sweet and tempting aromas.  Flavor is smoky-sweet with some heavy chocolate and coffee, peat, some pleasant hop bite......really nice smoked that tingles and brings the fire!
Bottle (Sune) at ØLklubben. Black - brown head. This is very nice !!! Lovely smoked, sweetness, burned, chokolate, coffee. Bitter dry finish. Love it !!

Bottled sample via oakbluff. Black and opaque in colour with medium carbonation. Aromas of heavy smoke, dark roasted malts, caramel, molasses, and light cherry. Flavors are of smoke, strong black coffee, dark chocolate, caramel, and a touch of fruit. Heavy in the mouth, but balanced by the acidity of the roasted malt. Not a hint of alcohol flavor or aroma. Great stuff.

Very dark brown with a small tan head. Serious smoked malt aroma.  Taste is like sweet smoky BBQ sauce with richly caramelized flavors, and a slight essence of band-aid vapors. Delicious.  $6/16oz draft

Bottle. [ Courtesy of kmweaver ] Clear dark red / brown color, sparkling with a large, frothy, excellent lacing, mostly lasting, beige head. Aroma is moderate to heavy malty, strong coffee, light to moderate smoke, moderate hoppy. Flavor is moderate to light heavy sweet and moderate bitter with a average to long duration. Body is medium, texture is oily, carbonation is lively / fizzy. (261007)
Bottle. Really really nice. Hazy and very dark brown in colour with a medium sized tan head. Very well balanced with notesof malt, smoke, chocolate, coffee and with a somewhat bitter and dry finish.

Bottled. A dark brown beer with a brown head. The aroma is sweet with notes of smoke and chocolate. The flavor is sweet malty with strong notes of roasted malt, some smoke, from beech wood, as well as some chocolate, leaiding to a dry bitter and roasted finish.

Big thanks to BBB63, Secret Santa in July for this one. Smells of alcohol and bread. Pours black with a small tanned head. Quite sweet with heavy grainy aromas. Also a bit of toasted grains. Smoke with a hint of salami. Medium to full bodied with a slightly sticky mouthfeel. Soft carbonation. Simply incredible palate. I like the sweetness that is very well balanced with the smoke. Nice and unpretetnitous complexity.

bottle.  black with thin tan head.  smokey, meat, coffee aroma.  smooth.  mild chocolate and coffee.  This beer is dominated by smoke.  The balance is good and the smoke is enjoyable.  Not much else to it.

Clearish, dark brown coloured. Light off-white film slowly diminishes. Rye-like, heavy, almost roasty, nutty nose. A powerful nose for a powerful beer and an interesting monster at that. When Left Hand tries hard, what they can do is truly impressive. Solid sweet maltiness procures notes reminiscent of hazelnut and caramel whereas the secondary flavours verge toward almond, roast, chocolate and spicey rye notes. Thick bodied, medium carbonation. Sweet ice cream, vanilla and leather finish. Relatively complex and varying flavour range. Pretty good beer though not that smoky and peaty more than rauchy.

750 2006 vintage Montreal tasting.  Pours black with a 1 finger light brown head.  Super smoky nose, peaty, with some mega knock you on your ass pow.  Taste is smoky roasty, with a lot kick, this is a damn grade A smoked.

In short: Top-of-the-class Smoked Imperial Porter
How: Mtl-crew beer-and-spagatt tasting.  Bottle from I-dont-remember-who.
The look: Black body with a very small beige head
In long: Medium intensity smoke.  Creamy body with a chocolate cake feeling.  Dry cacao and coffee beans.  Light astringency touch in the finish.  Up there with the Calumet Grand Chef on top of the Smoked Porters mountain.  Very tasty but never aggressive.  The nicest smoked porter since that cool pot-smoking Jamaican that was carrying my luggage.

220z bottle: Pours a very dark brown with a notable tan head. The aroma is pure roast with hints of coffee and molasses. The flavor follows the aroma The palate is well matched to the style with a nice soft coating.  This overall character of the beer is very enjoyable. Cheers to Left Hand!

The pour from the caged and corked 750ml bottle is deep brown to black in color, the head a nice chocolate brown, as it erodes, and the lace forms a thick and glutinous curtain that obscures the glass. Start has a rich deep burnt grain aroma, hints of hops and malt, a bit of smokiness also present, Top is light to moderate in feel, and the finish has a good hop presence with a pleasant acidity, fairly dry and a nice Porter overall.

My Bottom Line:
Smoked almonds decorate the healthy evening roast in this masterful, nourishing Imperial Smoked Porter. Surely one of Left Hands greatest achievements.

Further Personal Perceptions:
-A veil of foam tops the brown-sleeved black.
-The body is full and beautifully firm.
-Malts develop more than roast and smoke; coffee, dark chocolate and nuttiness even celebrate.
-The only thing left to do is to have a taste-off with Bièropholie Grand Chef. Oh, and buy lots of each.
-This is not good because its big and intense; its great because every flavor is well calculated and ingeniously integrated.

Bottled in 2006.

750ml Bottle:  Aroma of smoke, bacon, and wood.  Poured dark black in color with a medium-sized tan head that lasted throughout.  Small lacing.  Opaque.  Flavor of smoke, chocolate, malts, and bbq sauce.  Medium body.  Average texture.  Soft carbonation.  Smokey finish.  Overall, very smoky, but nothing else.

750ml bottle shared courtesy of egajdzis. Poured a dark brown color with an averaged sized off white head. Aromas of smoked meats, campfire, with some roast, chocolate and earthiness. Real nice smokiness. Tastes of smoke, chocolate, and roast. Light to medium alcohol finish.

Draft.  Very dark in color.  The aroma is all smoke - Mesquite.  This beer definitely is too smokey for my palate and tastes.  I had to fight to get through this one.  I see it has a large following, however I am not one of them.

Dark mahogany colored beer out of the bottle with a brown foamy head.  Rich, campfire smoke nose.  The smoke flavor dominates the beer, with lots of barbecue, campfire and honey glazed ham flavors.  Chocolate, caramel, burnt toast and alcohol all play under the smoke.  Really nice smoked beer.

25oz bottle.  shimmering motor oil hue.  its got head for days! aromas thick of bacon fat, bbq pits, hickory chips, and the oak monster.  its big, its smoky.  taste?  heavy, thick bbq pit smoke, roasted and almost toasted burnt toast, black coffee; its big.  major smoke all over the palate and finished off w/ rich unsweet chocolate.

750 ml bottle shared at Andrews bachelor party.  Pours a dark brown with an off white head.  Smoky nose, wood bacon and that "campfire" surrounding it all.  Chocolate, smoke, molasses, and a light sweetness are all balanced really well.  A touch of alcohol and a medium body.  Of all the beers i tried warm, left over, out of the bottle the next morning this was the best.  I guess it was those smoked flavors that bacon that made it good for breakfast.  I kinda want more now just thinking about it.
Black colour with a light brown head. Smoked, light sweet aroma with fruity notes. Malty, coffee bitter flavor with a balanced skoked note.

At the Palm Tavern with Jeff- Dark brown color, light brown head. Nose is chocolate, a bit of smoke, dark fruit. Cocoa powder. Sweet malty body, well balanced and sweet upfront, finish is dry, alcohol is well hidden.

Appearance is black with a thick tan head. Aroma is of smoke and some roasted malt. Flavor is nicely smoked, taste somewhat of smoked meat with a nice malt backbone. Very slight roasted coffee taste underneath the smoke. I really like this style and this is one of the best ones that Ive had so far.

This is good sh*t.  Olive, cedar, light smoke and horsey aroma.  Mildy acidic and peaty.  Nice balance.  Chalky finish over coffee.  Got to talking and didnt over-analyze, but the long and short of it is that this is a really fine brew.

Bottle from GoldtwinsThanks!Pours a rich, deep, brown with an aroma of of campfire smoke and sausage.  Seriously, theres some hot/mild links in there; just sniff for awhile.  Nice smokey flavor that gives a hint of what a decent campfire should be; aroma and flavor are almost perfect.  This is a beer that should be sampled  by EVERYONE.
user_location: Ugly, Hot, and Humid Spring, Texas, USA

text: A nice beer from start to finish, I just wish it had a bit more smokeyness to it than there was. Aroma was dark chocolate a touch of wood, but not nearly enought smokey character in the nose for my liking. After diggning a bit deeper there was a bit of charcoal, and molasses present. Appearance was stunning. Big thick khaki head, solid deep brown color with a garnet hue next to a bright light. Mouthfeel was a bit overcarbonated. Flavor had much more smoke presence that the aroma, but for me it just wasnt enough. I thought Alaskan SP was a much better example of the smokiness in a smoked porter. Some flavors in this beer were smoke, burnt wood, chocolate, toffee and a touch of molasses to round it out. The alcohol content gets kicked up a bit towards the end, which is a bit of a letdown. A nice beer for sure, and Im glad I shared it with my brother because Im not sure I would want to drink 750ml of this.
This was an AWESOME beer...I really like the smoked porter type beers and this one is up there with Alaskan Smoked Porter.

Poured a dark brown / red color with a small, light tan head that left nice lacing on the glass.  Aroma of smoked wood, char, sweet chocolate, and roasted malts.  Taste of chocolate, with roasted malts, and a large, dry, smoked wood taste, almost a bit salty, with bitter hops, and a fair amount of alcohol in the finish.

Bottle: Deep brown, moderate to large light brown head, fairly sticky lacing. &nbsp Huge smoked nose, campfire, charred wood, and 

more smokiness. &nbsp Getting a little alcohol too. &nbsp Subtle porter underneath the heaps of smoked malts, campfire, ash, and charred 

wood. &nbsp Has a slight bit of bacon to it as well. &nbsp Has a subtle milk sweetness to it, some roasted malts, quite smooth. &nbsp Clean 

finish. &nbsp Moderate to full bodied, smooth mouthfeel. &nbsp Was a little difficult when it was colder, but as it warms it seems to mellow 

a bit. &nbsp Enjoyable, even if a bit over the top in regards to its smokiness. &nbsp I can appreciate this one even tho the style doesnt 

do much for me. &nbsp Thanks Nick for the bottles!

Name: Smoke Jumper
Date: 12/29/2006
Mode: Bottle
Source: Bullochs, Marietta

solid dark brown, big dense creamy tan head, streaks of lace, sweet smokey aroma with dry chocolate that eventually comes through, creamy body, rich chocolate flavor, lots of smoked wood, nice bitter finish, picks up a nice peppery character after warming

Aroma: 7/10; Appearance: 8/10; Flavor: 7/10; Palate: 7/10; Overall: 15/20
Rating: 3.7/5.0Drinkability: 7/10
Score: **4

Bottle. Pours a dark brown body with a large fluffy yellow-brown head. The aroma is very bacony and pleasantly smokey, cocoa, and heavily roasted. Very nice integrated flavour profile. starts out chocolatey and tastefully smokey. Interestingly enough it never becomes overpowering. Some chewy resin is evident along with the roasty malts. 
Thanks for sharing this stuff, HogTownHarry!
Dark, almost black, of color with a brown head. An aroma of smoke, sweets and salami. a flavor of smoke, notes of sweets and spice.

Bottle (750ml) shared with HogTownHarry, GregClow, mds & tupalev -- courtesy of HogTownHarry. Pours a very dark brown with a large lasting fluffy beige head. Aroma is big time bacon baby! Oh yeah, that smells mighty fine! Lots of roasted malt and smokey bacon along with some chocolate and herbal hops. Wonderful flavour of roasted malt with lots of smoke, some alcohol, herbal hops and chocolate. Dry finish. Hides the alcohol quite well. Medium to full bodied. Friggin awesome, I loved it!

Bottle shared with Blankboy, GregClow, Mds, and Hogtown Harry, Harrys bottle.  Stunning smoke aroma - beer breaks through too - some roast and malt but wow - smoked bacon yet outdoors like campfire smoke as well - fantastic.  Very very dark brown, thick frothy beige head.  taste is excellent - rich malt, lots of  smoke, some bitterness from hops?  alcohol?  other?  Complex layered levels of smoke here - great contemplative stuff.  Powerful and not for those afraid of smoke - truly stunning.  Thanks for sharing Harry!

Bottle shared with blankboy, HogTownHarry, mds and tupalev - courtesy of HogTownHarry. Deep, deep brown with a medium sized dark tan head. Aroma - campfire! And bacon! Mmmm! Great mouthfeel. Big, big flavours of roast malt, smoke, oak, chocolate, dark sugar - just fantastic stuff.

Bottle (750ml).  Shared with blankboy, GregClow, mds and tupalev - my bottle.  REALLY looking forward to this one.  Poured near opaque black, with a large, lasting creamy/rocky light speckled brown head, a dull sheen to it like pancake batter (5-).  Wonderful smell - roast bacon, campfire, dry herbal hops, dark roast malt, smooth, lightly lactic.  The taste is very big - hides the 10.5% - again campfires, charred oak, almost coffee bean level roast malt, damned fine, long complex finish.  Thick body, all that smoke and roast makes it even lightly acidic, long malty and somewhat bitter finish.  DAMN this is a fine beer - top marks!

From a 750mL Bottle, 2006 Vintage.  Courtesy of footy.  Bottle opens with a tremendous crack.  Careful pouring reveals a dark black color with transparent edges of root beer brown and a tall head of fizzy charred tan.  Smokey nose with an almost greasy burned pork fat aroma.  Perfumey smoked maplewood coals grilling a pork tenderloin while a skillet of dark chocolate mole sauce simmers nearby.  A pot of dark percolator coffee bubbles next door and the campground dinner is ready to be served.  Medium bodied, highly carbonated mouthfeel.  The bubbles scrub vigorously on the tongue, but the weight and size of the fizz is light enough to be soft, yet not quite creamy.  Some sweet dark chocolate syrup greets the tongue first, softened with a hint of vanilla bean.  This, of course, is buried beneath a layer of damp, smoldering aspen bark.  Hints of earthy black peppercorn shells and toasted coconut husks.  Dark chocolate roast coffee; not overly bitter or astringent, but plenty dry.  Finishes dry and charred, a bit overly so, with a lingering smack of sizzling pine resins.  Very intense smoke flavor with great complexity right away - I find the smoke and dark malt complexities to get lost behind the hops in the dry finish, though.  The body is also slightly overcarbonated and not as supple as Id like it to be.  In spite of this, the flavors and nose are most pleasing overall.  Thanks, Rudy!

06 Bottle - Dense black, creamy light tan head.  Intense nose of crispy fried bacon, burning wood, and ashy cocoa.  Room temp brings about soft grapefruit and herbal-like tones.  Monster smokiness up front slowly fades into earthy, choco-coffee flavors.  Rounds out with very nice dose of grapefruit hoppiness.  Warming ABV without a doubt.  Medium bodied, soft carbonation, dry, smoked bitter finish.  A fantastic smoke beer in my book......not that I have written one...

Very well carbonated, even when poured carefully into my tulip glass it still produces a four-finger thick, brown tinged, dark tan colored head.  The beer is a slightly murky, opaque, dark brown color.  The aroma screams smoke, as even as I pour this beer I can smell the smoke influence.  Ahhhh, the aroma reminds me of my clothes after a night sitting around a campfire; man I love that smell.  Honestly, I am not sure that I can smell anything else but the smoke character; but still I am quite happy to sniff away at this beer for quite some time before I take my first sip.

This beer is fairly well carbonated, but the body is thick enough that it is really hard to tell that.  Malty, with a complex sweetness up front; notes of chocolate and slightly burnt caramel.  This beer is clearly dominated by the smoke character; it does not start to take hold until the beer starts to slide down the throat, but once it does it becomes, by far, the most noticeable thing here.  If you like smoked beers (and yes, I certainly do), then this will be right up your alley.  The smoke flavors provide some spiciness to this beer that mixes in the finish with notes of roast malt, bitter black coffee notes and a certain roast grain astringency.  It is hard to describe, but the smoke character is quite complex here; the smoke adds a sort of sweetness here, some spicy, sometimes hot phenolics in the finish, as well as an inviting, campfire component.  This last is the most noticeable note (though I have the hardest time describing what it is) and is perhaps similar to the smoke flavor a heavily smoked hunk of meat might pick up.

While the Porter character does not hit you over the head, it definitely is a huge part of the flavor profile, it really allows the smoke character to come through quite well without totally dominating this brew.  You will definitely have to be a smoke lover to like this brew though as this beer is just over the top smoky, though not quite one dimensional.  The is very enjoyable & I even wish I had an extra cases of this lying around as this would be a great beer to incorporate into food recipes; and it will definitely age quite gracefully for many years to come.

750 ml corked bottle served at room temperature; vintage 2006 - bottle conditioned.  Poured black with a rich foamy head.  Aroma was a pleasant powerful woody smoke.  Flavor was slightly bitter.  Alcohol was definitely present but the huge smoke balanced it nicely.  Mouthfeel was good with a strong carbonation tingle that lasted throughout the glass.  I loved this beer.

This 2006 corked & caged bottled brew from a bottle shop poured a extremely large sized head of finely sized brown colored bubbles that were mostly lasting and left behind a opaque dark brown colored body. The strong aroma was smoky and dark malt. The mouth feel was tingly at the start and at the finish. The flavor contained notes of dark malt and smoky. Delicious and one I would certainly buy again.

750ml. thanks to holdenn for sharing this bad boy. pours black with small white head. nose is extremely meaty and smokey. flavor is smoked meats and toffee. alc well hidden. very very tasty. mouth feel a tad thin. the best left hand has done so far for sure.
C&C 750. Black with a beige head. Nice, smoky flavor a bit of burnt malt. Woody smoke finish. Easily the most drinkable of the style Ive had. Excellent, albeit a tad pricey.

2006 Bottle:  The body is a very dark brown with a modest yet sustained tan head that does some slippery lacing.  Fine rauchbier aroma of peat smoke and Virginia ham over some chocolate and roasted malts.  (Honest.  The combination works.)  The high alcohol level is a bit of a distraction in the flavor, my preference being for a more sessionable smoked beer.  Still, the smoke and chocolatey roasted malts are smoothly blended along with a woody, earthy hop bitterness.  The finish is dry and full of smoke.  Not too shabby.

Bottle and served in my Stone IRS snifter: A deep brown hue with an initial huge frothy beige head and outstanding lace. The aroma is pure bliss with a proper amount of smoked and peated malts, chocolate and sweet malts, hint of espresso,  and even a dose of grassy/herbal hops. The taste is smoky for sure but I think the balance of nutty and mocha malt and a surprisingly noticeable piney hop bitterness kept this beer very drinkable. The finish is ashy dry and even a bit woody. The mouth feel is dry as mentioned, soft carbonation and little note of alcohol. Dangerously drinkable indeed. A wonderful expression of the style that I thought for sure was underrated until I logged onto the beer itself...

Thanks holdenn for this beer.  Dark brownish color and somewhat opaque with no head.  Smoke aroma that you can smell a mile away with a little malt.  Rausch smoke, choclate malt, little else.  Thin and no carb.  A crazy smoked beer, very good.

Dark brownish black color.  Sweet smoky malt flavors.  Not too smoky by any means.  Farily even and very drinkable.  I thought it leaned more towards the porter and less towards smoke.  Rich and smooth palate.  Good.
Thanks Immy. 750 ml bottle. Date 2006, 9.2% ABV. Pours black in color with brown head. Aroma of malt and SMOKE and more SMOKE. Taste of roasted malt and SMOKE.

Corked and caged 2006 bottle conditioned. Label says 10.%ABV. Large tan fizzy head that was mostly lasting with a fair amount of lacing, opaque, dark brown hue, and no signs of carbonation. Malty, roasty, smokey aroma and ditto for the flavor. Tingly mouthfeel and medium body.  Not a favorite style of mine, but this one is pretty good and worthy of a try.

Smokey, caramel, and vanilla in the aroma.  Pours black with a tan head.  Smooth vanilla and chocolate with some coffee, with a sturdy smoke background.  A great beginer smoke beer, for those that like porters/stouts.  Very smooth, not as smokey as a rauchbier, but very drinkable for the alcohol %.

Appearance: Pours a brown-black, near opague body with a diminishing, light brown head.

Smell: Abundantly smokey! Beyond the smokescreen, theres some roasted malts, rich caramel, dark chocolate, and smoked sausages.

Taste: Just a little too excessively smokey for me, as for me the imperial porter qualities are smothered under a blanket of smoke, sausages, and chimney sweepings. Sure, theres dark malts, caramel, French Roast coffee, and even some piney hops, but your tongue has to be ready to excavate it from beneath all the smoke.

Mouthfeel: Medium-bodied. Mild carbonation. Slight creaminess.

Drinkability: If youre looking for a smokey beer, than this brew will happily rub some salt into the wounds that such beers as Aecht Schlenkerla Rauchbier Urbock and Alaskan Smoked Porter have begun to fester within you.

Huge rocky head. Light-brown witha haed thats long lasting.  Black color.  Lots of great roasted aroma with mild coffee and chocolate.  Smokiness is definitely present, but not overpowering.  Lots of malt, as well.  Lots of carbonation  Not too overpowering smoke in the taste.  Very smooth and I couldnt really taste the alcohol, but could feel it as it warmed up.  Its been a while since I had an Alaska Smoked Porter, but would like to do a head to head comparison.

Bottle, thanks to jrob_21 for this!  Pours brown from the bottle, but ultimately looks black with a light tan, almost Belgian-esque head the way it formed so quicky and hugely.  Aroma is definitely that wonderful rauchbier smoke that I love, but theres a bit of roast, chocolate, and toffee behind it as well.  Flavor balances the ingredients a bit more, and thats even more evident in the second glass.  Dark chocolate and smoke merge as one effortlessly with some licorice just to spice things up.  Finish is holds a lot of woody smoke, coffee, and butter hop flavor.  Actually, the finish and aftertaste are so full and nice they might hold more flavor than the actual beer!  As good as the flavor is, this is one of the best aftertastes and finishes Ive tasted.  This is a pretty creamy beer and somewhat high in carbonation, but the mouthfeel is overall very nice.  A little bit of heat as it warms, but nothing too appalling.  If "smoked imperial porter" sound like your thing, then this beer will satisfy you.

Bottle.
Dark brown coloured with a beige head.
Roasted and smokey aroma.
Roasted aroma of liquorice, chocolate and smoke.
The smoke is very dominating in the aroma, but is more well balanced in the flavour.
Bottle. A almost black beer with a big beige head. The aroma is of smoke, licorice and smoked eal, so is the taste. Medium body with a dry smoked finish.

(Bottle 75 cl) Courtesy of CaptainCougar - 10.5% version. Pours a dark brown with a tint of red and a lively, dense, beige head. Aroma of smoke and sweetish, roasted malt. Full body full of very sweet, roasted malt and some burned accents. Quite smoky - Bamberg style - with a malt astringent finish. 160607

Bottle. Large creamy off-white head that lasted for a very long time. Impressive display of lacework. Color was dark mahogany. Aroma was of cause a good amount of smoke. But also some lovely molasses, chocolate, coffee and burned malty notes. Over the palate, some wood and liquorish was also detectable. Medium bodied with an average carbonation and warming alcoholic texture. Moderated sweet flavor with light bitter notes. Smooth, rich and thick sweet finish. The sweet and smoked goes well together.

C,C 750:bottled in 2006. Thanks to eaglefan538 for this smokey sumbitch! Received a medium statured tan head from eagles pour, retention was decent with minimal lacing which was spotty at best. Impy. Porter darkness ensued. Nose is ummmm, smokey with some berry notes and maybe, just maybe some caramel malts coming through. Whoa, smoke. Body is med/full, creamy, lightly oily and friggin smokey. Lots of smoked flavor, bacony, slim jimmy, charcoaly goodness, chocolatey with some Impy. Porter notes buried way back in there somewhere. Finish is almost dry, smokey with some faint remenents of a porter in there. A smoke lovers dream i am sure!? Thanks Brian!

Poured a deep dark brown black color, mahoganey hues, huge generous carbonated head, good retention, decent but not stellar lacing. The aroma was all smoke, lots of slim jim, meaty, smokey. The flavor was initially hard to pull anything outside of smoked meat. Higher temperatures gave way to some porter-like qualities. Too much smoke going on, but I would probably say the same about Schlenkerla too, neat treat if youre thinking smoke instead of porter. Body is full, but a little light for an imperial porter. Does smoke thin an impy porter?

Bottle. Pours deep oily brown. Smells of wet campfire and roasted malt. Creamy on the palate. Definite smoky flavor profile. Starts and ends with smoke. Nice complexity midpalate. Dry molasses. Hint of earthy peat. Bit of raisiny sweetness. Im not a huge fan of smoked beers, but this is good for its style.

2006 bottle left out of the fridge for 15 minutes before opening in goblet.  Pours thick brown-black with huge brown head that grows after pouring, little lacing.  Aroma of wood smoke, bitter chocolate, bread (?).  Flavors of roasted chocolate, wood smoke.  Bitter finish with lingering chocolate sweetness.  Full-bodied but slightly overcarbonated.  After a while, when completely warmed up, the flavors are better melded and the carbonation leaks out.  This is a delicious beer.  I would have only wanted a softer carbonation.  I still prefer smoked porters that are not Imperial  because I like to session them.  I drank four Alaskans in a row at Toronado, but I dont think I could do that with this.  Anyhow,  A+ for effort.  Cheers to bold brewers who brew bold beers.

Re-rate:  When completely warm to near room temperature, this is much better.  Mouthfeel is softer, lacing is excellent, carbonation has escaped.  Points added in palate and appearance.  good brew.  Cheers.

750ml bottle from 2006.  Pours a midnight black with a ridiculously thick, meringue-like tan head.  Aroma is a bit strange at first.  I noted a sharp smokiness very similar to a heavily peated single malt Scotch.  Then you notice the more typical cocoa and coffee aromas you expect.  The first taste is dominated by the smoke again.  But after several sips, a more complex mix of chocolate, caramel and dark fruits.  A lingering bitterness finishes the beer.  My first smoked beer -- its a keeper!

Pours deep, dark, ruby-hued mahogany, with a large, creamy, tan head. Strong aroma of smoked/roasted malts, a bit of chocolate, and lots of sweet fruity undertones with notes of plum, and raisins most present. Very smoky, and slightly peaty flavor. Not the overly meaty flavor you get from some smoked brews, but a bit of the fruity undertones I expect from a full bodied porter, a bit of mingled chocolate, and nice dry smoky bitterness in the finish. Palate is medium/full, creamy and silky smooth, slightly bitter, dry, a bit chocolaty, and yes....smoky. Alcohol is slightly noticed, but really only adds to the complexity of this brew. This is an exceptional offering from Left Hand: easy drinking, yet flavorful and complex. Definitely a must try.

CBF07, what I can understand was another of Jeppes bottles (Ill see if I can get replacements for this in the states), this time shared by someone else at the Mikkeller stand. Pours brown and amber. Aroma is roasted malts and slight smoked. Flavour is dry malty, smoked and goes into a good and decent bitterness in the finish.

Courtesy boboski.  Pours black with a medium light brown head.  Smells like smoky bacon and campfires.  Big, big smoke.  The taste is quite smoky as well, but with some nice chocolate.  Very nice that the taste isnt all smoke, but just a right amount.  Very thick, oily mouthfeel which is very warming and coats the palate.  The aftertaste is really chocolatey and delicious.  Greta brew.

Dark dark dark brown...beautiful...dark tan head...rich smoky aroma with malts breaking through...malty body blanketed by smoke, smoke, and more smoke...medium weighted on the palate...finishes with bitter hops...smooths out as you drink it

Bottled. Pitch black coloured. Dense brown head. Smoke, butter, sweetness and alcohol in the nose. Flavour has loads of chocolate, alcohol, smoke, tar and liqourice. Medium bodied. A chocolatish smoked end. Nice one.

Big smokey malt aroma,some acaramel and vanilla in theretaste is creamy mocha and chocolate milksurrounded by a light smoke cloud of flavor,not as smokey tasting as aroma would indicate,smoked wood and roasted finish. One of the best American smoked brews I have tried. They nailed this puppy

2006 Bottle - Dark brown body, light brown head; Smoked chocolate and burnt chocolate in simple nose; Huge almost weizen like carbonation, bitter slightly sweet; Medium long alcoholic sharp slightly bitter milk chocolate sweet finish.

750mL bottle, 2006 Bottle Conditioned, and my bottle claims 10.5%.  Pours a clear very dark brown with a three finger brown head, which continues to grow for a bit.  Lacing everywhere.  Aroma of smoked meat, charred wood, chocolate, roasted malts, and some light pine.  Flavor has a lot of smoke again with some added molasses, light spicy alcohol--doesnt taste 9.8% (maybe 8, tops) strong.  Nice addition of tobacco leaves and burnt caramel to the flavor.  Moderate carbonation with a full body.  Glad I have another one of these from BleacherBum to save for a while.  It doesnt hurt that I enjoy smoked beers, but this was a very good effort from Left Hand.
user_location: Ocean Beach, San Diego, California, USA

text: Bottled at Københavnske Øldage.  Dark hazy brown, creamy head. Smokey licorice aroma. Dryish with quite strong flavour of woody smoke. Medium sweet with full body. The high alcohol sines through, but doesnt disturb, instead it adds complexity. Very good smoke ale!

750ml bottle.  Pours a deep dark brown color with big frothy tan head that fades quickly into 1/8" head.  Aroma of smoke, chocolate, malt, some dark fruit and alcohol.  The taste lets the alcohol really show through.  Taste is smoke meat, roasted malt, light chocolate and possibly a note of anise.  The alcohol is well hidden and its quite a robust and creamy smoked beer.  Excellent!
Dark brown with a huge thick tan head. Aroma of smoke, wood, roast and some malt. Flavors of smoke, meat, malt, roast and some chocolate. Fairly well balanced and the smoke is not overpowering.

UPDATED: AUG 13, 2007 A Mes rate: 
Nice 75cl bottle at Ølfestival 2007. First off I have to say thanks to Henrik for pouring me some of this as it was being sampled at the Mikkeller stand. A true gent. Dark black brown colour with a pretty impressive tan head. Smokey alcoholic porter nose that to be honest is not amazing but I just love smoked beers. Considering the obvious trouble the brewer has gone to to smoke this beer I find it a shame that the smoke is very faint in the flavour. Would have liked it even more if the smoke was a little more assertive. That said the flavour is still pretty impressive with lovely malts, chocolate, slight liquorice and some faint English cheddar from the smoke. Plenty of alcohol showing however and it is just about bearable. Typically American in its lack of finesse but all in all still a jolly fine drop.

Dark Brown Color with Sandy Head. Heavy Creamy Mouthfeel.  Coffee Roast, Smoke Aroma. Burning and Smoke Enflame the Mouth...Creamy Lactose Flavor Balancing it Out...Coffee Roasts and Bitter Chocolate. Alcohol Well Hid.  Aside From a Flare Up of Smoke Flavor, This Brew is Well Balanced.

22 oz. bomber. Ruby tinged black/brown body under a lasting head of creamy tan foam and some slippery lace. The smoke is immediately very evident, although not as smoky as the beer from Bamburgs Schlenkerla Brewery. Addtionally, some maolasses, coffee, and a little chocolate makes a showing, but it all takes a back seat to the smoke. The mouthfeel is rich, creamy, lightly carbonated, with a hint of astringency. Flavor shows some pretty good balance between a malty sweetness and some peppery bitterness. Finishes dry, with some chewiness. If you like smoked beers, this is a good one, and the best Ive had from Left Hand if Im not mistaken.

Thanks beer_hawk for this brew. A super smokey aroma with a slight bitterish smell to it. A huge dark brown pour with excellent lacing. A flavor of super smoked oysters. Must me about as much smoke in this beer that can be captured in a brew. Just a tad over carbonated. Overall a very good beer. I hope to pick up another and enjoy a larger longer sample. Thanks Steve
Huge nose, ham and metallic. Nice meaty, chocolate taste with lot"s of alcohol that unfortunately totally numbs your tastebuds after a few sips. Nice example of it"s style though!

Pours a dark brown with a big ass light tan head.  Looks thick.  The nose is in fact thick. A significant smoke presence over a big malt backbone with hints of alcohol.  Chocolate malt and some roast definitely sneak in as does just a smidge of grape maybe?  Less emphasis on the coffee, more on the smoke, which I like.  Reminds me of Stone Smoked Porter.  The body is viscous with a good amount of carbonation and just enough carbonation to give this a creamy feel.  the flavor is certainly on par.  Big sweet malt, caramel and chocolate, meets head on with the smoke and the alcohol.  Something resembling bacon about this smoke, like the Schlenkerla Marzen.  the roast is a little more obvious here, getting into charcoal territory, but not overstepping that.  The alcohol is very forward, but I think in a brew with this much malt, not a bad thing.  Theres definitely a fair amount of diacetyl in here, but given the bigness of this brew, its covered up rather well, and in fact smooths this beer out to some extent.  Big round malt up front.  Roast acidity takes hold in the finish, with the acidity turning to alcohol with some floral hops showing up in the aftertaste.  For half the price, which was 11 bucks, Id drink this once a month.

UPDATED: APR 27, 2007 750mL bottle drunk on 4/20/07Nice to see a bottle conditioned left hand beer and the appearance confirms it.  Big, cascading, dark-brown head billows up and recedes very slowly, though only leaving minimal lace.  Medium to medium-high clarity, little, if any sediment on bottom.  Very dark brown body, with an oily/ashy sheen to it and cranberry highlights.Not much smoke in the nose, more like a coffee bean aroma with lots of medium-dry chocolate.  Hard notes of black malt takes things very dry and theres a bit of yeast blandness/doughiness.  Cola and more chocolate, with only a late, very dry woodsmoke-like note coming on the end.  The more I sniff for the smoke, the more Im greeted by lots of chalkiness, doughiness and a very strong overtone of vanilla and somewhat hard coffee notes.  A bit of solvent/glue-like vapors on the end as well.  Medium to medium-strong strength.The body opens up rather watery, with a somewhat loose carbonation and surprisingly light body.  Chocolate-covered coffee beans seem to be the dominant flavor that I get, followed by a little bit of "day-after-campfire" notes.  Some oiliness further disrupts any consistency that the mouthfeel could use and dark, roasted malts throw on the coffee bean-like notes as alcohol is strongly persistent on the end.  More smoke comes with warming, a slight saltiness mixing with sweeter chocolate notes, but the alcohol never goes away and the body stays rather light, the carbonation too loose and the beer just seemingly too big for itself.  Too forceful for me, without enough succulent smokiness or ample body to pick up some of the heavily dry, coffee/roasted hardness and alcohol.  Oh, and I forgot the hops.  Theyre poorly done, to say the least.  Bitter, acidic and without much redeeming flavor or aroma, they exacerbate the effects of the alcohol and create a stinging, harsh sensation on the palate.

From a caged corked 750 ml. bottle with a bottling date of 2006, a blurb on the back, stored at cellar temperature and allowed to warm up a bit before sampling in a pint glass.

Poured a reddish hued blackish coffee brown with a foamy, bubbly tan head that settled into a thin creamy, sudsy lacing, minimal amount of sticking.

Aromas of smoked pork, roasted chocolate and toffee malts, molasses, tannic and charcoal.

Good steady moderate carbonation like you would expect with a decent porter, and a crisp, dry, slick, creamy smooth medium bodied mouthfeel.

This is different, in a good way, from other smoked porters Ive tried by the smoked meat taste at the beginning, followed by burnt chocolate, toffee and caramelized sugar, a little expresso bitterness, charred wood, tannic, while warming in the palate, the alcohol is barely noticeable until at the end when it emerges in the taste, and a dry smoky, malty finish with a lingering earthy bitterness.

One of the better brews Ive had from Left Hand, an easy sipping smoked porter, well worth trying.

UPDATED: JUN 24, 2013 One of the coolest labels Ive seen in a long time.  Two-color airplane and smoke jumpers diving into a burning forest awesome.   The pour is deep brown or black color, very dark body with a medium dark brown head which settles into a film.  Nose is a bit sweet, thats my first impression, the smoke isnt heavy but the sweet cream and milk notes are probably the most dominant.  Creamy and thick body, slick, chewy texture, with a flavor predominant composed of more of this milky smoked malts and even some coffee and toffee.  Good stuff, mixes the smoked porter qualities well with the imperial porter sweet qualities.  Isnt something miraculous but it certainly tastes good and its very drinkable.

Pours an opaque black with dark brown edges and a large, over-carbonated tan head with lots of clingy lacing.  Sweet dark caramel and dark chocolate aroma has good complexity of dark fruits and nice smokiness.  Body starts with a full dark malty sweetness and smooths out once the carbonation wears off with good mildly earthy, and salty smoky balance.  A nice, complex smoked brew.

Has a pretty solid bacon aroma.Pours dark brown with a medium tan head.Flavor has a good amount of chocolate malt and a mild smokyness that doesnt over power.Medium mouthfeel with a malt/slight smoke finish.

Pours deep brown-black with a tan head. smells very smokey, deep smoked wood, salmon or pork some cheese or lactose as well. Tastes not as smokey as it smells, some sweetness like a chocolate in the background. syrupy and fairly complex. berries. Finishes with some alcohol and a bitter roasted chocolate. Very nice.
Black, thick tan head.  Nose is campfire, iodine, chocolate.  Flavor is caramel, smoke, cocoa, a bit of piney hop recedes into general bitterness.  Tar & smoke finish.

Dry salty pork and liquid smoke aroma.  Almost black with a decent head.  Medium palate.  Taste is medium roasted malt, and some bitterness in the finish.  The smoked aspect doesnt dominate, but plays a very nice supporting role.

At first I thought this had too much smoke flavoring--like drinking liquid BBQ--but after a few sips, that impression took a back seat to the obvious awesomeness that is this beer.  Really...its not too smoky.  Its good-and-sweet and one hell of a porter.

On tap at the Left Hand tasting room.  Deep black impenetrable color, nice thick tan head.  Aroma is nice  dominated by the smoke.  Palate is slightly thinner than expected, light carbonation.  The smoke kind of over powers the flavor, if it were toned down a bit, this would be way better.  As the beer warmed I started to pick-up some roastiness and a bit of coffee.
Pours an almost black with a thin brown head. Smells of smoked meat. The flavor is simply smoky with malts and slight alcohal

Ill say up front I am a big fan of smoked beers, so you can take my review with that in mind. Poured nearly black from a 750 ml bottle. It had a big, creamy brown head. The aroma was of smoked cedar. Had a smokey taste, as expected, with lots of chocolate notes. The alcohol really came to the forefront of this beer. I will say it is rather pricey ($13.99 in TN) so it is not an everyday beer, but a great one to reward yourself with. (If you dont like smokey beer, this one is not for you. After my wife had a taste, she said she felt she just drank our fireplace - which was not a compliment).

4-Apr-07  750ml bottle.  Really like the silk screened logo on this bottle.  Beer is deep ruby-brown, blacker towards its depths, with a sturdy, dense, tan head of fine bubbles.  Aroma is at first a nice burst of dusty smoke atop gritty roast and coffee.  With temp, the aroma evolves and less welcome aromas emerge, something, not quite plastic, but it reminds me of that waxy makeup smell like when your grandmother would pop open her compact.  Whatever it is, its not right.  Palate is nice, unctuous, grippingly dry for such a big beer (feels dirty).  I cant decide if the stuff is trying to be rustic or refined.  An acidity lingers, not unlike other big porters, but its lasting with a tongue coating feeling a bit like old coffee.   Alcohol presence is obvious and mildly intrusive as the beer nears room temp.  Smoke is not persistent in the flavor as much as I hoped it would be, but its no slouch, either.  In all, Ive been arguing with myself about this for the entire 750 ml.  Ive had this pegged anywhere between a 2.9 and a 4.0 but I think Im settled somewhere between the two but nowhere near the almost 4.0 average the rest of ratebeer has doled out.
22oz bottle-pours a light brown head and black color.  Aroma is dark coffee grounds, beef jerky, smoky.  Taste is smoky, dark malt-molasses, faint licorice, coffee.  OK carbonation.

Dark with a foamy residual brown head.  Smells of smoked meat.  Taste is huge and complex.  There are a variety of smokey flavors, salty esters, caramel malt, and a slight alcohol.  Wonderful, complex, and satisfying.  Wouldnt want more than one though.

25 oz bottle, via cewldre.  Pours an opaque dark brown, almost black, body under a generous two finger brown head that climbed out of my snifter.  Aroma is a wonderfully balanced combo of campfire smoke, roast, caramel, chocolate, bacon, and light hops.  Flavor is more Imperial Porter than Smoked though.  Roast, caramel, and a chalky ashiness up front, followed by some burnt malt and smoke on the slightly alcoholic finish.  Mouthfeel is medium-full bodied with moderate fizzy carbonation.  Finishes a little sticky with a throat warming alcoholic kick.  A pretty nice beer.  I love me some smoked Porters.

black pour with dark beige creamy bubbly head.  aroma of sausage and chocolate and oak, with some bacon and barbeque smoke and a little espresso.  flavor is a LOT of smoke, mostly barbeque pork and oak flavor with some vanilla and espresso.  hints of chocolate and bacon.  now see i love smoked beers though so while some people may think this sounds gross, i adore it.  nice creamy mouthfeel too.

Drank one of these that had spent a day open.  If its this good after way too much air, cant wait to crack open a fresh!  Dark brown color with lots of smoke in the nose.  Flat because of how long it had been open.  More woody smoke in the body but didnt get much else.  Ill re-review once I open the bottle in my fridge.

UPDATED: MAR 26, 2007 Let the drinker be aware that a correction should be made on the ABV. The percentage on my bottle says 10.5%, but as I ve seen it is actually only 9.8% very upsetting! The aroma of this beer was great. I believe I rated it higher than others, but I feel that the aroma is very complex. The smell of smoke, chocolate, and wood hit your nose at different times, and I have yet to pour my beer. As I just finished pouring the smell of smoke is very noticeable. I have seen others raters talk about the massive amount of head, I actually did not experience this aspect of the beer. The color is a nice dark brown/black color. The palate is dissappointing. The beer is too carbonated. The beer is also not thick enough. The taste is pretty nice. Very complex. The hint of coffee, chocolate, wood, smoke, and leather are all there. A complex beer, and a very smoked beer with a disappointing ABV. Also, I should note that the palate really kills the taste(s) of this beer, which is why I am only giving the palate a 2.

UPDATED: APR 3, 2007 Pours black, big brown head.  Smells like smoked meat.  Flavor is sweet with lots of smokey goodness, but the aroma can be overpowering at times.  The alcohol is almost not noticeable, though it sneaks up on you.  I am feeling it right now.

UPDATED: NOV 20, 2010 Applewood bacon, campfire, and molasses! This is a wonderfully malted, subtly roasted rauch bomb, with a nice hop presence to keep things from becoming to soupy. Im not even a huge fan of the style (particularly not the traditional Germans - so sue me) but between Alaskan, Stone, and now this, I could become a convert.

750ml bottle enjoyed during the 3rd annual St. Pats day celebration.  Dark chestnut pour with a light wispy head.  Medium amounts of smoke in the aroma which always remind me of salmon.  But there is also some nice roasted malt and a light sweetness.  The flavor has a good dosage of smoked grain but not as overpowering as the Alaskan Smoked Porter.  Light sweetness of molasses and caramel and perhaps a hint of chocolate.  Not a favorite but not bad for a smoked brew.

Just a cool looking beer, obsidian black with a big tan head. The aroma is subtle, smoky like an early morning fireplace in the neighborhood. The smoke flavor is really nicely balanced with a chocolate, vanilla, and cream texture.

Black in appearance with a crazy big tan head, despite my best efforts at a gentle pour.  Aroma has that characteristic aroma of little smoky sausages that so many smoked beers seem to have.  Flavor is somewhat more balanced, with chocolate flavors balanced by an overarching smoke flavor.  For those who are into smoke being a major part of the flavor profile, this beer should prove quite satisfying.  If you prefer your smoke notes being more subtle, this might not quite do it for you.  The low score here is indicative of my personal preferences, not that this is a "bad" beer.

Bottle  shared at the Tennessee Spring(ish) Tasting. Poured black with a frothy white head. The aroma had fruit and malts with a nice blend of smoke.  The flavor had smoked malts that reminded me of beef jerky. The smoke was not overloaded like many other Smoked brew but more evenly blended. Medium to full body with a dry smoky finish. I could see this going really good with a barbeque.

UPDATED: AUG 17, 2009 Praise be to Beer Hawk for bringing a bottle of smoked beer to the Tennessee Spring(ish) Tasting in Knoxville, TN on 3/10/2007.  How did you know that I loved smoked beers and have been dying to try this beer?!  Thanks again Steve for sharing...

SmokeJumper is a dark brown brew.  It has an inviting smoky malt and fruit aroma.  The flavor is filled with smoke, but it isnt over the top by any means (actually, I would have preferred a bit more).  The smokiness has a well crafted realness to it and isnt ashy or burnt-tasting in any way.  It is just a nice, smooth, full, and slowly infused smoke quality.  There is also some solid roasted malt and fruity flavors underneath the smoke.  The finish was slightly dry, but the alcohol content was otherwise well hidden throughout.  SmokeJumper has a medium body with an average level of carbonation.  Smooth on the palate.   This is a very well crafted and balanced smoked beer.  Just a bit more smoke next time guys!  Score:  8/4/8/3/17=4
. . . . . . . . . .
2006 Bottle Conditioned
1/11/2009:  Left Hand SmokeJumber Smoked Imperial Porter...  Aroma:  Choclate, fruity/caramelized malt, brown sugar, moderate smokiness with a touch of creamy yeast and mocha.  Appearance:  Depp mahogany brown color like the color of heavily caramelized sugar; large, foamy, lasting brown head; web-like lacing marks.  Flavor:  Mild meaty smokiness thats almost barrel char-like; milldly roasty, balanced caramelied maltiness; coffee/mocha-like finish; lightly bitter resin and leafy hops; slight walnut flavor when warmer.  Palate:  Medium-bodied, light and airy on the palate, carbonation level is starting to creep upwards.  Overall:  Fairly well-blended flavors, but needs more smoke for my preference; Would pair nicely with cheeses and chocolate; Smoke barely comes through the flavor after the first few drinks then the beer tastes more like a good porter or stout; the smokiness is more of a roasty/char character and is reminiscent of the rind of smoked cheddar cheese; tastes similar to burnt choclate rather than really being smoky.
1 Pint 9.36 fl. oz. corked and caged bottle (Alc. by Vol. 9.2%) from Rivers Bend Wine & Spirits in Maineville, Ohio.  Score:  7/4/7/3/15=3.6
. . . . . . . . . .
2008 Bottle Conditioned
8/13/2009:  Left Hand SmokeJumper Smoked Imperial Porter...  Aroma:  Chocolate blended with meaty smoke, dark malts seem to come through more that the smoke right now.  Appearance:  Very deep brown, pretty much black color; thin beige.  Flavor:  Concentrated smoke up front followed by quite a bit of chocolate and an orangy hop bitterness that seems a bit out of place in this beer.  Palate:  Medium to medium-full body, slighly milky, average palatte.  Overall:  Still pretty good, but obviously production now that the silk-screened 750 mL corked and caged bottles are gone...

1 Pint, 6 Fl. Oz. capped bottle shared by metmayhem.  Thanks !  Total score:  3.4

UPDATED: APR 10, 2007 I will premise this rating with the declaration that I do not like smoked beers. However, Beer_Hawk brought this to the Knoxville Tasting and I gave it a try. Pours dark brown with a tan head. Aroma of purple grapes  and roasted malt, not a ton of smoke. Medium bodied with medium fine carbonation, but very dry on the palate.  Nicely balanced flavors of peaty smoke, coffee, pepper, and bakers chocolate. There is a  small amount of sweetness in there to keep it in balance. The alcohol is masked very well on this one.  This is a well crafted beer, and by far the best from Left Hand. As much as I dislike smoked beers, I could see myself drinking this with good BBQ pulled pork or steak. The $12 price tag may prevent me from doing that. For those who are looking for subtle or faint smoke, stay away. Thanks Steve.

750ml bottle, corked and caged.  Pours a dark brown with ruby highlights.  It has a monstrous light brown head that retains and laces the glass.

The aroma is lots of smoke (liquid smoke and fire with some BBQ coming out as it warms), grains and some chocolate malts.

The flavor is sweet, slightly sugary, malts and a touch of dark fruits with a large smoke presence.  It has a crisp, moderate hop finish.  The alcohol is well hidden, but is definitely there.  The mouthfeel is medium to full bodied with slightly sharp carbonation.

Overall, this is an excellent brew!  This is what I had hoped for from Stones smoked porter.  If this was cheaper ($11 per 750ml), Id buy this all the time!

Very rich aroma, with a pretty well-balanced smokiness.    Otherwise coffee, roasted malts and a good campfire-woodiness. Oily, dark brown body, small tan head.  Good, "natural"-tasting flavors.  The smoke is not too over-powering,and the earthiness comes through too.  Whatever the alcohol content is, it is pleasantly warming.

750 from Julios - dark brown pour with a large, off-white head - nicely smoked aroma, with natural charred wood smells, roasted malt, and a hint of dark fruits - creamy mouthfeel, with some milky sweetness up front - the smoke in this beer is intergrated into the roasted malt flavors better than Ive ever tasted in any smoked beer - coffee and chocolate mixes well with tobacco and woody notes - this is a very nice smoked beer.
Black, with a huge tan head. Aroma is smoked ham. Or smoked eels. My notes say smoked eels, so lets go with that. Smooth and smoky flavors, as one might expect. Only slightly bitter i the finish.

bottle at Dickinsonbeers on 1/20/07.  creamy burnt sienna head, cloudy light brown body and golden at edges.  aroma is smoky cured meats, flavor is smoked malts.  a little bit of beef jerkey in the finish.

UPDATED: MAR 10, 2007 thanks zeswaft.  well, immediately bacon.  its almost the same thing as the urbock rauchbier but its a bit weaker.  texture is rather harsh but probably apt for the style.  very carbonated.  in fact, everything about the style is harsh.  pure smoke.  i enjoy the novelty, as always, but the mouthfeel kills me.  bottle says 10.5% abv.  god thats huge.  doesnt come through at all.

I always shutter when I think about a smoked beer.  Luckily this time Im about 6-7 beers deep.  This is one volatile beer.  It doesnt gush when you pop it but when you pour it bubbles everywhere.  Has a pretty big smoked meat/camp fire aroma but not too unappetizing.  It doesnt seem like the smoke pervades the flavor that much to me.  Theres a lot of chocolate in the underlying porter.  Its a pretty good beer and I wish i could rate it as high as everyone else but its still a pretty gross style.  ps. 10.5% is huge and i didnt realize.

Thanks Chuck!  The beer pours to a really dark brown/black body with a huge nice looking dark tan head and great lacing.  The aroma is smoked dark malts, roasted barley, and chocolate.  The flavor is deeply smoky chocolate malt and nicely toasted barley.  The palate is moderately full bodied, creamy, lingering smokiness.  Balanced and also a quality brew!

Thick frothy tan / light brown head. Very dark brown body. Smokey cattle barn, dry smokey wood, sweet chocolate stuff. Nice rounded smokiness with sweet brown sugared wood. Drank, enjoyed, not really described.

Dark black pour w/ a thick tall reverse cascading head and some nice lacing.  Very smoky aroma definate camp fire almost like sitting next to a grill w/ burnt chicken breast hints of charred wood chips and touches of chocolate.  Palate is nice fairly rich lightly creamy.  Flavor is quite nice not overly smoked like my thoughts of the aroma.  A nice smoky chocolate with lots of dry woody coccoa and some more chocoalte.. mmm roasted chocolate next to a campfire.  This tastes very good.

Bottle shared by Chuck.  Black body under a dense, thick tan head.  Wood smoke and bubblegum in the strong nose; enjoyable.  Rich, strong chocolate/berry and wood flavor with gentle wood char on top.   Similar finish.   This is a damn good porter with a well-balanced smoke addition.

wow, this is such a good beer. not just a good smoked beer, but a good beer.  dark oily black body with a lasting coating gray head. smells lightly of snmoke, but, cured leather and old barn wood is what i get. a touch of the sweet malt comes pout in the aroma too. the taste, well, it is what it is for sure. lasting tongue drying bitter and alcohol. dry cocoa, bitter smokey wood taste and a dry beef flavor. the smoke is light in the nose, very subtle with the coffee and cocoa taking the lead in the first taste, but the finish is that dry, libngering smoke note, that dominates. after every taste i spend a moment enjoying the change from bitter chocolate and spice to the alcohol dry stick my head in a smoker taste. it is just a great experience.

UPDATED: OCT 29, 2007 Pour is black but not so oily.  Aroma of chocolate mousse and leather.  Hint of smooth coffee bitterness.  Cedar smoke flavor and semi-sweet chocolate, some roast and black currant.  Medium to full-bodied palate, less commanding than expected; kind and pleasantly drinkable.
