This beer is very good for an American smoked.  The aroma is strong smoke, with roast beef and leather.  Flavor is smoky with some sweetness as well with a palate that is thiner than I expected from a beer with such a rich aroma.

Bottle - corked and caged. Pours opaque and near jet black. Only the faintest amount of light peeks through around the edges. Nose is roasty and very smoky. Light smoked meats, roasted malts, burnt coffee, burning wood and dark bittersweet chocolate. Taste is almost full on smoke. Smoked and roasted malts, lightly smoked meats, burnt coffee, and soft dark chocolate. Bit of caramel, as well. Body is creamy and smooth with an everlasting smokiness. Finish is bitter and smoky with more burnt coffee and burnt wood notes, light choco flavors, touch of caramel, maybe even burnt tomato-based BBQ sauce. The is very nice, though Im not sure how well it will age despite its high alcohol content and bottle conditioning. I believe I have an extra (Ive recently moved and my "cellar" is in a state of disrepair). Would go great with sausages, BBQ, and some seafoods!

I rate this beer as average mainly cause I have never had anything quite like it so there is room to grow.  The aroma is perplexing.  Youre not too sure whats coming up.  As for the taste, Im not sure how Left Hand was able to liquefy salmon dip but they did.  Was only able to try a small portion so it might have grown on me

Pours a nice dark brown/black with a decent dark tan head.  Nice bitter chocolate nose with a nice smokey overtone, and hints of wood chips.  Nice medium carbonation carry the delicate chocolate and toffee flavors through with the strong, but not overpowering woodfire smokiness.  There is a nice light floral hoppiness that helps carry the smoke and chocolate to the finish.  A wonderful smoked beer from the U.S., which is not very common.
user_location: Farewell Minny; Hello Puyallup, Washington, USA

text: At the 2007 Big Beer, Belgians, & Barleywines Festival in Vail. Pours black with a tan head. Wonderful peaty smoky aroma that has a flair of roasted coffee as well. Malty and earthy flavors surround a thick sorgum flavor. Very toasted and roasted. The smoke flavor is there, just not as huge as the aroma anticipates. Very delicious. Chocolatey and dangerously drinkable at this high an abv.

Pours dark brown with a light brown to tan head.  Smells of smoke, chocolate, some coffee, some dark fruit.  Taste is smokey with lots of dark chocolate and coffee elements.  Mouthfeel is velvety with a nice dark fruit and smokey finish.  Finally, a beer from Left Hand that I like.

UPDATED: AUG 31, 2007 22 oz bottle via Captaincougar (thanks!). Pours a thin dark brown/almost black with a huge beige head that leaves more spider lacing than any beer i have ever seen. Nose is smoke, vanilla, and more smoke. Taste starts wtih some sweet caramel, then some vanilla, some earthy/citrus hops, then the smoke kicks in. Finish and aftertaste are a nice blend of sweet malt, earthy hops, some toffee and lots of smoke. Carbonation is medium, body is medium. Drinkabillty is high. Alc well hidden. I think this is my favorite smoked beer thus far. Very very well-done and world class.

big and smoky in both taste and aroma.  i find a lot of smoke reminds me breakfast sausage and bacon which is a good thing.  it also has good amounts of caramel, toffee, coffee and chocolate flavors.  this is somke forward but balanced out just enoough where the smoke isnt all you get. this is highly recommendable.

Black pour, moderate head, good retention, blah lacing. Aroma is exactly what youd expect... very smokey with roast, caramel, chocolate, coffee and light hops. Flavor brings this, medium to heavy body with a fair amount of smoke. Very enjoyable. Alchol is hidden perfectly. The best beer Ive had from them easily.

(750ml bottle) Large and persistent tan head atop a brown-black body.  Aroma is medium sweet, overwhelmingly smoked Gouda, some caramel, chocolate.  Initially taste is medium sweet, chocolate, caramel, some smoke, roast, earthy.  As it warms, however, the smoke really asserts itself, pairing nicely with the chocolate character.  Alcohol is hardly noticeable despite the ABV.  Smooth medium body, dangerously drinkable.

The aroma was smoked sausage and chocolate with an espresso note. A nice ashtray smoky phenolic led the charge followed by some strong chocolate and coffee with a backbone of malt. The beer poured clear black with an amber hue and a tall tan head which rose tall and fell slowly to lace the glass. The flavor was malty with caramel and chocolate held in place with a strong smoky presence, like summer sausage. Some espresso coffee was notable with a lightly grassy hop presence behind the smoke and mirrors facade. The body was medium full and with a moderate level of carbonation and a creamy mouthfeel. A very well achieved smoked beer with only slight hints at the true alcohol content of the brew, due to how smooth and drinkable the beer actually was. A winner, no doubt! 750 ml corked and bailed bottle.
user_location: North of Raleigh, North Carolina, USA

text: I unwinded the metal cap with the $15 pricetag and uncorked this beauty in a venture to warm my insides on this cold Virginia evening.  The aroma of a well-used firepit wafted to my nose promising that comforting warmth ... the crimson brown elixir looks warm enough.  The first sip is a bit of a surprise, with more a sweetness factor than Id expected.  The more I drink, the more Im perplexed by this beer.  While there is a definite ashy smokiness, theres also a combination of pine, bitter chocolate, and that lingering sweet, almost molassas bite.  Not as good as Id hoped for $15!  (#2706, 2/15/2007)

750 from JimboWood. Pours an opaque dark brown with a substantial and lacy tan head. Bacon and chocolate -n the nose - which turns out to be a pretty inviting smell. Full body. Chocolate, molasses and smoke taste, but the smoke never overpowers - this is a well rounded beer that even does a good job of hiding the alcohol.

750, courtesy the kind generosity of BitBucket. Amazing stuff. Pours a deep opaque black with a thick, fluffy tan head that sticks around. Big smoke, chocolate, and bacon nose. Lovely forward attack with plenty of deep hibachi smoke, roast, chocolate, and thick oily meaty flavors on top of a medium-high body. Tingly bitter finish, more smoke than resin, but a bit of resin in there as well. If there was a bit higher body and deeper flavors, this would be a true world-beater of a beer--as it is, its pretty fantastic.
Pours a deep brown color with a tan head.  Aroma is of sweet and smoked malts with some chocolate.  Flavor is sweet malt and smoke with a a bitter chocolate finish.

Got this one form BeerandBlues2.  Pours a dark muddy brown with a big foamy brown head.  Barbque smoke character with some chocolate and roast.  Maybe even a touch of hop aroma?  Smoke leads the way over the tongue, but isnt overly domanate.  Nice chocolatey flavor with a sort of slick mouthfeel.
Thick brown head. Tones of smoke in aroma like smoked sausage. Also hint of coffee and some malt. Would go excellent with any smoked food.

750mL bottle.  Pours a dark, dark brown core; light tan head with web-like lacing.  Generous smoke, charred malt, and dark chocolate aroma.  Full, dense, smoky mouthfeel: charred and roasted malts; pleasant robust porter maltiness underneath; well put-together.  Long, smoky and charred malt finish.
750 ml bottle:  its a porter and its dark.  this is a great beer.  nice smoke presence that isnt over powering.  sweet malty chocolate and coffee flavors.  A+  will drink again soon.

UPDATED: FEB 11, 2007 Unlike some other smoked porters, the smoke isnt overpowering; it blends well with the loaminess of the underlying porter. Smooth. Mid-weight mouthfeel. Neither sweet nor bitter. Very complex. (Going to cellar a bottle for 6-8 months or so...just to see.)

FlavorFULL. Whopping roasted malt and smoke aroma. Pretty straight-forward here. Great wood-smoked flavor, but nice crisp carbonation. Barbecued Beer! Really interesting for a first smoked beer, pour moi. Some coffee and dark chocolate flavors in there as well. Lasting flavor on the palate. That lingering smokey bite like I just ate a pile of ribs.....RIBS! Wouldve gone great with the smoked chili last week. Great brew, but lets have some food with it fo sure!

Lovely pour, pitch black with a towering creamy tan head that leaves really nice glass lace behind. The aroma is loaded with smoke, roasted malt, chocolate, and some alcohol. The flavor is sweeter than I expected and not as smoky as I would have liked. It is very hoppy, too hoppy I think for what they are trying. Medium bodied. The goos is that it stays true to its porter roots without turning into yet another imperial stout, the only bad is that it is either too hoppy or not smoky enough. I think that it is the former and not the later. Still it is enjoyable.

I was looking at this beer on the site the other day, and was shocked when I walked into the local store. I had all intentions on only buying a 6 pack of a random IPA to consume while bowling.....needless to say I walked out with a bit more than a 6er....anyway it pours out black with a medium sized tan head. Aroma was of smoked meat with some sweet notes. Flavor is very complex and smooth for the ABV. Wood smoke flavor goes into some chocolate with molasses and some roasty notes. Very interesting beer, I like it.

UPDATED: JAN 31, 2007 2006 bottle.  Black pour with an enormous, tan, rootbeer-floatesque head; very large bubbles settle leaving a small, frothy remains and minimal lacing.  Nose is rauch with underlying porter characteristics; meaty/smokey notes with earth, burnt dark chocolate, and roasted coffee backing.  After the head dies, the smoked meat note dies down letting the dark malt notes come out better, also noting burnt caramel and anise now.  Flavor is much more approachable once it warms; notes of rauch, wood, dark chocolate, roasted peanuts, light coffee with acidity to match, and burnt caramel.  Bitterness is moderately low but the smoke notes make up for that.  Palate is medium-full, moderate carbonation, and fairly viscous, almost oily.  Finishes mostly dry with rauch, earthy hops, and burnt dark chocolate with mild acidity still lingering.  Nice offering  with the smoke and the porter flavors being complimentary.  For me, it could have used less of a smoke presence to present the other flavors to stand out more, i.e. Stones Smoked Porter.  But Im sure rauch lovers would tell you the opposite.  Not being a huge fan of aggressively smoked beers, this still works pretty well; however, I did find myself liking it much better when the head setted and it warmed to almost room temp.

750ml pours with a strong carbonation and a large brown head.  Body is pitch black.  Aroma is good smoke with some burnt, roast, and chocolate behind it.  Taste is lower on the smoke (booo) with light roast.  An easy drinking beer with a medium-light body.  Just a bit of bitterness at the end of the taste to round it off.  I would want more int he taste and a thicker body.
user_location: HdG (past: NYC, KS, Rain City), Maryland, USA

text: Bottle from Sams.  Poured into my Spezial Brau Rauchbier dimpled mug-finally a worthy beer to put in it.  Pour is dark dark brown with a light tan coloured head which retains quite nicely. Nose is smokey with hints of milk chocolate, roasted malt, and coffee. Flavor is not as rich or smokey as I expected. First, there is roasted chocolate malt and subtle hops, then a good amount of smoke hits the palate. This is a nice beer, but not the best smoked Ive ever had. Having said that, Ive never been a huge fan of the style (smoke flavor) but this is a good hybird rauchbier to introduce people to the style. Much easier to drink than expected. My favorite smoked so far, but i still have that alaskan in the cellar.

At first this was overwhelmingly smoky and killed any sort of subtleness the rest of the beer was showing.  After getting used to the smoke you realize there is some good dark cholocate and bittersweet flavors behind the smoked malt.  Very entertaining  but not something I want to drink on a regular basis.

Rating #500!  I shared this bottle with my buddy Novak.  Beautiful brown color.  Tight tan colored head.  The aroma does it all for this beer.  Smoke aroma brings a nose of salami immediately.  Slight roasted malt flavor with chocolate and coffee.  Not too much cause the light smoke flavors take over just right.   Flavor will pair perfectly with salmon or even a Bacon-Gouda Burger. YUM.  I loved this smoke beer...

Corked Bottle at 48F. Poured dark brown with a large light brown fizzy head that was mostly lasting with very good lacing. Moderate woody smoke malt aroma. Medium body. Medium sweet roasted smoke flavor with a medium bitter finish of moderate duration. Complex standout beer.

bottle shared by Danthemansp, thanks!  very dark brown, near black in appearance.  Aroma is alot of chocolate, smoke, and maybe some licorice.  Taste is alot of chocolate, some roast, with a good deal of smoke.  Big and flavorful, I really liked this one.

This poured a very dark brown to black color with a small beige head.  The aroma was very smokey butpleasant.  It laid nicely on top of the roasted malt.  The flavor was the same tasty roasted malt with a nice smokey flavor on top.  Medium bodied.

Corked wire trimmed bomber. The pour was a thick chocolate black/brown with hints of red, creamy tan head. Nose was roasted, smokey caramel, with hint of hop/citrus. Now for the taste. Flavor was chocolate and roasted porter, with ending hints of citrus, the whole thing had a wonderful essence of smoke, but not like licking an ashtray. Very nice, from a none smoke guy. And at $13.00 for the bottle, a great try but far from an everyday drink.

Pours dark brown with a small tan head.  Aromas and flavors are very smoky like a campfire.  Its BBQ in a bottle.  You could marinate a side of ribs and the cook at the same time.  Its expensive, but worth it.

Bottle... This beer rocks!... Murky, pitch black ale with a small, fizzy, khaki head. The aroma is a rich swirl of chocolate, campfire smoke, blackstrap molasses, tobacco, booze and wood. The flavor is rich with sweet and scorched chocolate malts, smoke, tobacco, molasses and alcohol. Full-bodied and velvety with medium carbonation. Lengthy, molasses-caramel, smoky finish. A touch spendy at $14 per bottle... and a little hot right now, but a world class brew in my book! Combines all the great characteristics of a rauchbier and Baltic porter!

750 ml corked and caged that I picked up at Belmont Party Supply in Dayton.. - Pours black with a fair creamy tan head that stays well and laces the sides of the snifter that I consumed this from.  Good smoky aroma with plenty of roasted malt behind that and some good chocolate aroma as well.  Flavor is subtle smoke with nice full bakers chocolate, and roasted malt flavors with a touch of citrus in there as well.   Slight campfire at the finish with a slightly fizzy palate and good smooth body.  Alcohol completely covered.  Im not usually a fan of Left Hands average brews but they have a winner here for sure.. Wow nice!

750ml bottle.  . Smoky aroma - like smoked salmon. . 	Black pour, fluffy tan head. . 	Malty with smoky overtones and a bitter bite from roast malts. .	Medium body, full carbonation. .	Wow - a very complex smokiness from a big beer.  Would be great after another 6 months.

750ml. corked bottle. Dark brown, nearly black color with a small beige head. Nice smoky aroma that was not overpowering. A bit of meat, but mostly the aroma is wood smoke, along with dark chocolate and roasted malts. Flavor was lots of chocolate malt, fairly mild smoke, vanilla and a somewhat bitter hop finish. Carbonation was a bit on the high side, which took a little away from the mouthfeel. Alc. was barely noticeable, except in the effect after the bottle was finished. Very enjoyable, but expensive beer at $13+/bottle.

UPDATED: MAY 22, 2007 Opaque dark brown pour with a chestnut border. Slowly receding tan head with superb retention. Aroma is at first wrought with heavy smoke, a total surprise, and just what I was hoping for though I didnt know it until this very moment. Parts of the aroma are bordering on the nuances of German rauchbier, like a more full bodied version of Schlenkerla Urbock. Also pleasant is a small hop smell, another pleasant surprise, just trickling through the waves of smoked malt. Flavor is again huge, complex smokiness at the fore. Roasted malts up front, sweet at first and then drying. This beer is very balanced and VERY full bodied. A middle of the road finish(not too oily and sweet, or dry and brash) is quite pleasant. Plenty of smoke throughout but not overwhelming. Left Hands best beer to date? For my money, yes. Warmer temperatures bring about a vegetal character that just adds to the complexity. Excellent. Well done Left Hand!

Near black in color with a foamy, sudsy dark tan head. Dark roasted grains and  dark chocolate with hints of smoke and black olives. Fairly mellow in scent. Roasted malt mingles with a a touch of pale malt sweetness, peat, molasses, and a dry vanilla extract. Feel is smooth, but dries up with a banana pith quality. Alcohol comes out as it warms. Earth hops meander about, but dont seem to fit in as well as one would hope. A interesting smoked brew that I would enjoy with brisket or ribs anytime.

Bottle: I am not sure where the bottle says 10.5% because my bottle says that it is 9.2% abv on the bottom left of the silk screened label, but I digress. Anyways, pours a very dark brown, almost black. The head is a nice white with a little bit of a reddish hue to it. The smell, well, I think WOW sums it up. The smell smells like smoke, as I should have expected. It smells like some sort of meat is cooking over a campfire, maybe some pork. Its an incredibly intense, thick smell, much like a wild fire would produce. After the smell, I am a little weary of what the taste may bring, since I could barely whiff the beer without feeling like something was wrong... much like a fire. The taste is not quite as intense as the smell, but it is still amazing. This beer has a little bit of everything. I note a lot of meat still, like pork cooking over a fire as I noted above. I also notice some chocolate, which only compliments the nice meaty flavor. I feel like I am sipping on a nicely smoking piece of meat. This is great.

Poured black with a thick white head.  Interesting hardwood-smoke aroma with some roasted malts way in the background.  Taste is smoky, meaty, and features a nice chocolate character that is great and balances the brew nicely.  Slight bitter finish.  A great smoked beer.
Courtesy jayg. Black. Modest tan cap. Big smokey campfire aroma. All campfire with subtle chocolate. Medium, smoother than balanced palate. Love that smoke. Great brew.

Pours thick and black w/ super full semi creamy froth. Aromas are deeply roasted, smokey sweet malts w/ cigar box and citrusy scents. Like a pine forest ablaze. Full nectar w/ very soft residual effers creating an oily texture. This is one heavily smoked porter. Heavy malt backbone like molasses. Sweet maple, roasted espresso bean, smoked jerkey, cocoa, old leather, and citrus rind. The finish is long and lingering w/ a perfect bittering from the hops that finally kick in. As this brew warms it really starts to balance out. The oily texture turn to velvet and the molasses mellows to brown sugar. Drinks better cool not cold. A killer brew none the less. I scored this perfect classic because of its duality. You get two brews in one. The cold version and the cool version (after its warmed a bit). It would be so easy for a brew of this decandent nature to get lost in itself showing a narrow, straightforward character. But this one pulls it off and really hams up its inherent complexities. Connoisseurs Choice! Highly Recommended. Get it while you can.

Pours a deep brown with a LARGE head that just wont quit. The aroma is smokey chocolate, and a touch of wood. The flavor is ruined a bit by the overcarbonation in this beer. It comes across as thin and a bit hot. Any richness from the malt whisked away by the intense carbonation before it can be savored. Smoke comes back after the swallow.

UPDATED: JAN 22, 2009 Bottle split with Muenster, Tronraner. Pours black, well, I might be able to see some red hues in the opaque body. Good firm tan head here. The aroma is a smoked meat extravaganza, like jerky, with some dark cigar notes. The flavor is just a bit less meaty and more porter like flavors come through. The finish is quite ashy with slight chocolate and a finish of hickory. Intense.

750 big thanks to TheBeerCellar! Pours very dark brown/black with a huge tan head. Man, this stuff smells so good. The bacon, campfire, and meat is strong in the aroma. It doesnt blast my nose, but it is way heavier and fuller than most other pansy smoked beers. Some black chocolate and coffee is hinted at behind all the smoked goodness. The mouthfeel is nice and rich, very even and coating. If the Schlenkerla line could have this kind of palate, those could be the perfect smoked beers. The smoked meat, though strong in the flavor, is a little less pronounced than it is in the aroma. Rich earthy chocolate comes out then fades into bacon, meat, cigars. The more I drink this stuff, the more I go nuts over it.  Sure, I could use more smoke, but this is a very robust beer as it is and everything melds together perfectly while still expoing the meaty ashiness I love. Left Hand really needs to release this again!

[January 22, 2009]

22 oz of the new stuff. This is very dark beer, its basically black and sports a nice tan head too. The aroma is smoky and meaty with bitter chocolate. Hops are actually kind of notable too. The flavor really accents the smoke more. Lots of meat, campfire, bacon fat. The malt profile is hefty and creates a nice mouthfeel. This is a very good beer, though I wish it were smokier.
Big bottle, thanks to tronraner and NachlamSie for this. Pours dark black with medium tan head. Aroma is strong smoky coffee, very robust, as is the flavor, strong chocolate and a sweet touch.

750 mL bottle. Pours opaque amber with a big beige head. The aroma is lots of smoked meat with some coffee and caramel. The flavor is smoked beef and coffee with some good typical porter flavors mixed in. The alcohol is very well masked. This is quite a tasty brew.

Massive foamy tan head (took up half the glass and I was being careful).  Black pour ... some light can get through if held up to a strong bulb but not much.  Wonderful chocolate, toffee aroma with just a hint of smoke.  Thick mouthfeel with a toasty roasted malt with a pleasing smokey flavor.  Fantastic beer!

UPDATED: FEB 24, 2007 Pours opaque and black with dark tan head. The aroma is thick with coffee, burnt toast, smoke, chocolate, and alcohol - perhaps hints of chicory, too. The flavor starts off bitter-sweet like an unassuming robust porter or a stout. Some roasted flavors and some sweet malts. The middle of the tongue finds some dark fruit, some chocolate, and some hops. The middle is also where the flavor of smoke begins to fade in. There are also some sweet malt flavors arriving in the middle - like caramel with hints of vanilla. The back of the tongue detects lots of bitterness as well as some alcohol. Really burnt, almost savory, notes, big hop bite (has to be big to make such a big beer taste balanced), and the sting of smokey alcohol all find their way to the back of the throat. The after-taste is full of bitter cocoa, hops, and smoke - and a little alcohol to warm the throat. The after-taste lingers but is mild. The mouthfeel is quite thick, but creamy and sudsy with carbon dioxide. The beer is quite smooth for such a strong beer, pleasantly palatable, and not too terribly smokey (my wife usually doesnt care for smoked beers, but even she was able to enjoy this one). It tasted absolutely delicious with our new years eve dinner of roast leg of lamb with roasted potatoes and red onion marmalade. Overall - excellent.

750 mL bottle.  Pours opaque with a tall foamy brown head, mostly lasting, good lacing.  Aroma is heavy malt (coffee, chocolate, bread), light hops (grass), average yeast (dough, leather) with notes of ash, wood, smoke and tar.  Long duration, average sweetness, acidity and bitterness; roasted chocolate and toasted malt, wood and smoke, leathery yeast flavor.  Full bodied, sticky texture, soft carbonation and a metallic finish.

750 ml bottle poured a clear nearly opaque  dark brownish black with a large lasting tan head. Aromas of smoke, charcoal and a hint of dark chocolate. Palate was medium bodied and smooth. Flavors of hardwood smoke, dark chocolate, charcoal, light carmel and a hint of vanilla with a lingering smokey finish.

I have liked almost every smoked beer I have ever sampled, and I had always wondered why more brewers didnt give the smoked treatment to their one off releases.  Almost reading my mind, the newly released corked and caged bomber of Left Hand Smoke Jumper Smoked Imperial Porter appeared on the store shelves of Bullocks in Marietta, Georgia.  I uncorked it without bothering to refrigerate it first, and the loud thud and the free forming head inside the bomber made me realize that had it been a few degrees warmer, and I would have had a geyser on my hand.  The beer looked opaque black with dark brown highlights when held up against strong light.  The large khaki head was impressive when taking into account the double digit ABV.  Inhaling the headspace over the beer revealed that the standard Imperial Porter aromas of coffee, chocolate, and roasted grains had been overlaid (or almost overrun) with the wonderful aroma of wood smoke.   The taste exhibited an assertive smoke treatment, which went well with the other bold flavors of chocolate, toffee, vanilla, and bitter hops.  More a stout than a Porter if you ask me, as there was little to no sourness, and the taste was more bitter than sweet, but take this as an observation and not a complaint.  Body was quite chewy, and the alcohol was warming in the belly (as if there was a real fire in here to go along with all the smoke).  Note to self, pick up more to cellar.

UPDATED: DEC 26, 2006 pours black with a huge brown head that lasts forever.  aroma of smoke, hops, peaches, and more smoke.  nice flavors of chocolate, vanilla, hops, and yes....smoke.  the smoke lingers long after the beer is finished.  i loved this.

This one pour an oily black color with a huge tan head that takes for frickin ever to die down. Aroma is intriguing. You get obvious smoke on top of a chocolatey American style Imperial porter scents. The flavor is very much a roasty burnt coffee flavor with hints of chocolate and Blackstrap molasses. I think the smoke flavor is what makes the coffee notes seem burnt. I like this one but I could actually do with more smoke and subdued chocolate hints.

750. Beer is very dark brown, nearly opaque with a large-to-huge, frothy, light brown, diminishing head.

Camp-fire heavy aroma. Its malty with a moderate notes of shortbread, toasted grain, light note of caramel; Hoppy with a light note of resin/pine; Light miscellaneous note of underripe banana.

The flavor is heavily sweet, moderately-to-heavily bitter, moderately acidic with a long, moderately bittersweet finish. Lots of campfire in the retros.

The body is full, the texture is velvety and the carbonation is lively.

UPDATED: JAN 5, 2009 Bottle (2008 batch). Head is initially average sized, frothy, brown, mostly lasting. Body is dark brown to black (not opaque, flashlight tested). Aroma is moderately malty (roasted grain, chocolate), lightly hoppy (resin, apricot), with notes of smoke, ash, and vanilla. Flavor is moderately to heavily sweet, lightly acidic, lightly to moderately bitter. Finish is lightly to moderately sweet, lightly acidic, moderately bitter. Medium to full body, creamy/velvety texture, lively carbonation, moderately alcoholic. Much improved from the overly-hoppy 2006 batch.  Thank you, Left Hand, for letting the malt and smoke shine through this time.  Still lacks nuance and finesse in the nose, but overall very rich and satisfying.  Good stuff.
